Author: "Butterfield, Tania"
Title: "Sense of disbelief in wake of night-time devastation; Shaky sense of disbelief"
description: "Reports on her tour of the city in the aftermath of the destructive earthquake in Canterbury on 4 Sep 2010. Talks to local residents and family members about their experiences."

Author: "Beaumont, Nathan"
Title: "Brace yourselves, Wellington; High time for Wellingtonians to brace themselves"
description: "Reminds that the capital city is considered overdue for a large earthquake, explaining the three fault lines that lie below it. Presents risk modelling estimates, and a possible scenario, for an earthquake of the magnitude that struck Christchurch. Describes the Wellington Earthquake National Initial Response Plan and illustrates the estimated time taken for recovery of services. Details damage caused by the 1942 earthquake centred over Masterton. Alludes to the general unpreparedness of city residents."

Author: "Morton, Frances"
Title: "When will it stop?; Canterbury tales; 'If I'm going to die I want to die with Jo'"
description: "Traces the week after the Canterbury earthquake for Christchurch residents. Talks to a number of people about their experiences. Provides a graph to illustrate the number of aftershocks that hit the region in the week. Presents columnist Paul Holmes' personal narrative about his visit to Christchurch after the quake, and Christchurch mayor Bob Parker's experience."

Author: "Cone, Deborah Hill"
Title: "Shaky ground"
description: "Looks at how NZ's two main television networks, TVNZ and TV3, covered the Canterbury earthquake. Talks to TV3's Mark Jennings, long-time television journalist Janet Wilson, and journalism professor Jim Tully for their opinions about the coverage."

Author: "Laugesen, Ruth"
Title: "Aftershocked"
description: "Looks at the chances of another magnitude 7 or more earthquake hitting NZ after the Canterbury earthquake and the possibility of predicting earthquakes. Touches on preparing for a big earthquake for the public and local authorities. Provides a map showing 10 years of shallow earthquakes in NZ."

Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"
Title: "When tomorrow came"
description: "Presents the author's personal experience of the Canterbury earthquake."

Author: "Lomas, David"
Title: "'Run for your lives!'"
description: "Recalls the aftermath of the 1968 Inangahua earthquake and talks to some of the survivors who also experienced the Canterbury earthquake (4 September 2010). Touches on the Modified Mercalli (MM) intensity scale and how it has been applied to major NZ earthquakes."

Author: "Matthews, Philip"
Title: "Quake a virtual reality"
description: "Reports on how news of the earthquake in Canterbury was reported in NZ and throughout the world via text messages, blogs, Internet news sites and other social networking media."

Author: "Van Beynen, Martin"
Title: "The day of reckoning; Amazing response"
description: "Reflects on the events of the past week since the magnitude 7.1 earthquake struck the region at 4.35 am on Saturday, 4 Sep 2010. Comments on the terror of the event and the multiple aftershocks, and the miracle that no one was killed and very few people were seriously injured despite the severity of the quake. Praises the rapid response of the population and emergency services and the relatively quick recovery of infrastructure and most businesses. Talks to people about how they are coping in the aftermath of the event, and describes the damage to homes and some historic buildings. Touches on future priorities for the region."

Author: "McCrone, John"
Title: "Focus on self-help best answer"
description: "Reports on the psychological effects of the 4 Sep earthquake for residents of the region, and the adjustments they will need to make in the coming weeks and months to cope with the aftermath. Talks to several psychologists and to residents Marge Straw and Peter Straw, to Bishop of Christchurch Victoria Matthews and Burwood-Pegasus community board chairman David East."

Author: "Steeman, Marta"
Title: "Already struggling, some businesses won't survive"
description: "Concentrates on the economic impact of the 4 Sep 2010 earthquake on the business community, particularly on the Christchurch central business district. Informs that there may be some economic gains in the medium term in the construction and related industries."

Author: "Anderson, Vicki"
Title: "Shock tactics"
description: "Talks to Christian Livingstone of the rock quartet about their decision to continue with their upcoming concert despite the recent earthquake, AL's Bar, Christchurch, 16 Sep 2010."

Author: "Gates, Charlie"
Title: "Mastering the reel life"
description: "Talks to the film aficionado and distributor about building his independent cinema business in Christchurch, his tussles with the cinema chain monopolies, and censorship. Reveals who sewed the arthouse theatres' waterfall curtains, affirms the high and low brow tastes of his shows, and mentions his home theatrette. Details the earthquake damage sustained by movie theatres in Christchurch."

Author: "Van Beynen, Martin"
Title: "Rebuilding answers lie in the soil"
description: "Explores the phenomenon of liquefaction. Examines earthquake-damaged houses in Kaiapoi, and a subdivision in Bexley wetlands originally opposed by the Christchurch City Council, which were affected by liquefying soil. Notes international interest by scientists and geotechnical engineers in the effects of the process. Talks to specialists about the susceptibility of soft soil areas, the contribution of this year's high water table, and the success of soil compaction techniques carried out at the new Pegasus Town near Woodend."

Author: "Gaynor, Brian"
Title: "Economic lessons from earthquake repairs"
description: "Looks at the likely impact of the Canterbury earthquake on the NZ economy and overall Gross Domestic Product (GDP) by using the economic situation in Chile after a magnitude 8.8 earthquake struck the southwest of that country on 27 February 2010."

Author: "Price, Mark"
Title: "A tale of two cities"
description: "Examines the nature of the relationship between the two largest cities in the South Island, taking into account the aftermath of the 4 Sep 2010 earthquake in Christchurch. Seeks views of health professionals, city councillors, civil defence authorities and businesspeople about the often unseen business, social and other interactions between the two cities."

Author: "Wall, Tony"
Title: "Fractured earth, broken hearts"
description: "Talks to residents of various Christchurch suburbs, including Brooklands, about the aftermath of the Canterbury earthquake. Briefly discusses using drama as therapy for children traumatised by the earthquake. Portrays the earthquake through the viewpoint of two young girls. Provides a personal narrative about the week after the earthquake and the impact on a poultry farm."

Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"
Title: "Architectural Alzheimer's?"
description: "Conveys concern that the restoration or demolition of Christchurch buildings after the Darfield earthquake may erase the city's architectural history. Discusses the main issues in post-earthquake restoration: cost, the decisions of private heritage building owners, and controversy over architectural design. Describes the work of the Christchurch Heritage Trust and its successes with heritage building owners."

Author: "Price, Mark"
Title: "Quaking in our boots; Standing up to the test; The last good shake; City stands ready; Built upon the sand; Old timers could get wobbly"
description: "Focuses on the recent magnitude 7.1 earthquake in Canterbury on 4 Sep 2010. Asks seismologists and others whether the Dunedin and the Otago region are likely to experience an earthquake of a similar magnitude and if so, how prepared the city is to cope. Focuses on civil defence preparations, discusses the possibility of soil liquefaction in low-lying areas and describes the characteristics of earthquake-prone buildings."

Author: "Dekker, Diana"
Title: "The ideas man, not the enforcer; Athfield the young rebel now 'that learned go-to guy'"
description: "Talks to the Christchurch-born veteran architect about his selection by the NZ Institute of Architects to serve as an 'architectural ambassador'. Talks about his decision to donate some of his time over the next six weeks to help his hometown recover from the earthquake. Describes some of the iconic buildings he has created in Wellington and his influence on the capital and NZ."

Author: "Schouten, Hank,"
Title: "Golden opportunity to revitalise Christchurch"
description: "Focuses on opportunities to revitalise the city centre following the Christchurch earthquake. Sums up a presentation in Wellington by Hamish Doig and Evan Harris of Colliers International Christchurch."

Author: "Anderson, Vicki"
Title: "When will the next one hit?"
description: "Talks to Robert Yates, professor emeritus in geoscience at Oregon State University, about his work and that of other geoscientists to improve the ability to predict earthquakes. Comments on the comparisons between the Canterbury and Haiti earthquakes, and expresses concern for other parts of NZ that have significant geological faults. Includes a map of the Alpine Fault."

Author: "Matthews, Philip"
Title: "The right architect for this job?"
description: "Asks if the Christchurch-born and raised architect, appointed by Christchurch Mayor Bob Parker as the 'architectural ambassador' for the city, is the most appropriate person for the task of providing advice in the wake of the earthquake. Overviews his career and seeks views of Christchurch architects Peter Beaven and Wellington urban historian Ben Schrader."

Author: "Monahan, Kate"
Title: "The gender test; Life put into perspective"
description: "Investigates the increasingly popular practice amongst parents to have antenatal ultrasound scanning to ascertain the gender of their unborn child. Talks to several mothers about their experiences, including  situations where the scan incorrectly indicated the gender of their children, and to a mother who prefers not to know her child's gender until it is born. Talks to radiographer Diane Somerville and sonographer Karen Lissington of Hamilton Radiology about the technology they use to determine gender. Seeks comment from University of Waikato psychology professor Jane Ritchie about whether parents are placing gender expectations on babies before they are born. Talks to the mother who was in the midst of giving birth to her daughter during the 4 Sep 2010 earthquake in Canterbury."

Author: "Hutching, Chris"
Title: "Quake upstages SCF aftershocks"
description: "Provides a general report on the impact of the Canterbury earthquake with an emphasis on property in Christchurch. Notes the recent payout to South Canterbury Finance (SFC) investors by the government deposit guarantee scheme. Provides Standard & Poor's Rating Services view on the financial impact of the earthquake."

Title: "Commission absorbs cost shock"
description: "Looks at how the Earthquake Commission (EQC) will fund the claims from the Canterbury earthquake. Provides information on the claims process for homeowners with earthquake (or aftershock) damaged properties, and the customer assistance bank packages available in the Canterbury region from ASB and ANZ National."

Author: "Anderson, Vicki"
Title: "The quake files"
description: "Takes an interesting look at whether there is any connection between whale beachings, unusual animal behaviours, tidal forces, chemtrails, mining and oil drilling and more with earthquakes."

Author: "Cairns, Lois"
Title: "The toll of leading a city's recovery"
description: "Speaks to the Christchurch mayor about his personal and practical response to the Darfield earthquake. Evaluates his odds in the upcoming mayoral election and conveys his changed attitude to politics."

Author: "Wells, Peter"
Title: "Some terrible obliteration"
description: "States how a city rebuilds its lost architecture, whether through war or natural disaster, is vital for its future. Compares what happened post-World War II in Europe where the author notes 'citizens of the city were comforted by a return of an architecture they knew and felt affection for' and what NZ's approach has been to the past. Recounts the rebuilding of Napier after the 1931 earthquake was constrained by the desire of the public wanting very strong buildings (reinforced concrete) and without high parapets. Designers had the example of Santa Barbara in California, which was rebuilt after a disastrous earthquake in 1925. Suggest Christchurch is entirely different, noting the destruction is in pockets and both historic and contemporary buildings have been damaged. Asks the question how will these Victorian and Edwardian buildings be rebuilt and asserts that Christchurch should."

Title: "Special powers in quake response"
description: "Outlines the Chapman Tripp response to Parliament's passing of the Canterbury Earthquake Response and Recovery Act (CERRA), focusing on the Acts three mechanisms: the Recovery Commission, Orders in Council, and protections from liability for certain acts or omissions. Cautions that implementation of the Act be monitored, given its significant and unusual powers."

Author: "Fletcher, Richard"
Title: "Act now, repent at leisure?"
description: "Ponders the legal consequences for post-earthquake Christchurch residents taking action regarding their property in the face of aftershocks, civil defence emergency requirements, heritage building issues, and other property complications. Questions the effectiveness of Canterbury Earthquake Response and Recovery Act (CERRA), and compares it to previous cover-all legislation, the Public Safety Conservation Act 1932 (PSCA)."

Author: "Ash, Julie"
Title: "Traumatised Gran quits one quake zone for another"
description: "Traumatised Gran quits one quake zone for another"

Author: "Moore, Christopher"
Title: "Lessons learned; Seismic lessons"
description: "Focuses on the likely effects of the 4 Sep 2010 earthquake on future building design. Talks to civil engineer John Hare, NZ Institute of Architects chairman Jasper van der Lingen and University of Canterbury professor of civil engineering professor Andy Buchanan about earthquake design over the years and lessons learnt from past major earthquakes and the most recent one."

Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"
Title: "Chance to change"
description: "Talks to architect Ian Athfield about the opportunity to reinvent Christchurch offered by the Canterbury earthquake. Looks at the pattern of destruction left by the quake, different from that of the 1931 Napier earthquake, and gives Athfield's comments on developing inner-city living, fitting new buildings in among the old, and how buildings and people interact. Discusses the earthquake strengthening work of earthquake engineers which helped save many old buildings, and the economic effects on businesses of the damage. Examines the problems in some Christchurch suburbs affected by liquefaction of the land."

Author: "Steeman, Marta"
Title: "Mainland monitor : rebuild managers appointed"
description: "Examines progress toward rebuilding the region, six weeks after the magnitude 7.1 earthquake. Seeks comment from spokespersons from the insurance and construction sectors and from the Earthquake Commission (EQC)."

Author: "Matthews, Philip"
Title: "Lesson from the past"
description: "Revisits the 5.6 earthquake that shook Newcastle, Australia, on 28 December 1989, teasing out lessons for  post-quake Christchurch. Gleans information about the opportunities for urban renewal and civic building, the dangers of demolishing and rebuilding too soon, the pitfalls in moving from disaster to recovery, and the juncture of when to remember and forget the event. Cites advice by Australian consultant Brian Eastoe on how to coordinate post-quake interests to avoid disputes. Ponders Newcastle's unreadiness, given the area's history of tremors every 60 to 70 years. Chronicles the saving from demolition of the Christ Church Cathedral by architect Barney Collins, detailing the preservation technology utilised."

Author: "Macdonald, Nikki"
Title: "Green growth"
description: "Examines the future of the Green Party now that Keith Locke is the only remaining original member. Discusses the new co-leadership of Russel Norman and Metiria Turei. Notes the party's stability compared to other minority parties. Profiles Young Greens co-leader Holly Walker. Indicates dissent over the Christchurch (Darfield) earthquake vote, and asks whether this shows a trend toward pragmatism over principles.  Talks to current and former Party members about whether there is a trend toward diversification versus activism. Ponders how the party will position itself at the next election, and whether the party policies are becoming mainstream."

Author: "McCrone, John"
Title: "What lies beneath; What lies broken beneath"
description: "Investigates the unseen damage to sewers in the city as a result of the 4 Sep earthquake. Talks to residents regarding the impact of the damage in their neighbourhoods and to Christchurch City Council water and waste unit manager Mark Christison about the preparations required to undertake repairs."

Author: "Hallett, Adelia"
Title: "What treasure lies under the quake rubble?"
description: "Talks to the professional conservator and archaeologist about the opportunity created by the 4 Sep 2010 earthquake to explore the rubble underneath historic buildings. Discusses her past experience working at British sites for the British television programme 'Time Team', and informs that an approach is being made for funding for a similar programme in NZ to explore sites under damaged Christchurch buildings. Speaks to Frank van der Heijden, Canterbury and West Coast regional archaeologist for the Historic Places Trust, about the history of the city and its stance on old buildings damaged by the earthquake."

Author: "Anderson, Vicki"
Title: "Billy T James"
description: "Talks to the Christchurch-born comedian about his memories of working with the late comedian, which he has captured in the release of a new DVD. Informs that he will perform at the Christchurch Art Gallery, 27 Nov 2010, to raise money for the earthquake relief fund."

Author: "Blundell, Sally,"
Title: "Does counselling really help?"
description: "Reflects on the response of the Government, aid agencies and counselling services in the wake of the Canterbury's earthquake to offer counselling to Cantabrians. Asks whether counselling is needed after a disaster without loss of life. Suggests of more value is social support and practical assistance. Reports the best form of support was the restoring of power and telecommunications, assisting with insurance claims and resolving water and sanitation issues. Indicates the need to watch out for those who may need counselling rather than making a blanket assumption about the need for counselling for all."

Author: "Power, J.  F."
Title: "Earthquake damages cashflows too"
description: "Talks about the case of a tradesman in Christchurch who cannot continue fixing earthquake-damaged chimneys and roofs because he is owed more than $160,000 for the work he has already completed. Suggestions what the tradesman did wrong."

Author: "Moore, Christopher"
Title: "Standing up for heritage; Aussie architects view quake damage"
description: "Meets South Dakotan Donovan Rypkema, an advocate for heritage buildings and their place in the 21st century. Talks to Australian heritage architects Barney Collis and Edward Clode, who visited the city recently to advise on what to do about heritage buildings that were damaged in the 4 Sep 2010 earthquake, and to learn about how to prepare for the next earthquake in Newcastle."

Author: "Shiels, Rosa"
Title: "We can rebuild it"
description: "Talks to the architect who is part of a group working with  Wellington architect Ian Athfield to rebuild Christchurch following the earthquake. Explores his style, and lists some of his design tips."

Author: "Macdonald, Nikki"
Title: "Greens' new colour"
description: "Examines the future of the Green Party now that Keith Locke is the only remaining original member. Discusses the new co-leadership of Russel Norman and Metiria Turei. Notes the party's stability compared to other minority parties. Profiles Young Greens co-leader Holly Walker. Indicates dissent over the Christchurch (Darfield) earthquake vote, and asks whether this shows a trend toward pragmatism over principles.  Talks to current and former Party members about whether there is a trend toward diversification versus activism. Ponders how the party will position itself at the next election, and whether the party policies are becoming mainstream."

Author: "Braunias, Steve"
Title: "The year beneath the earth"
description: "Reflects on the events of the year, dominated by the Christchurch earthquake and the Pike River mining explosion. Touches on overseas visitors to NZ (Hillary Clinton, Justin Bieber), the industrial dispute surrounding  the filming of The Hobbit, public service scandals, private fraudsters, sporting achievements, and a setting straight of the life of one of the miners killed at Pike River."

Author: "Fox, Michael"
Title: "Quake-rattled chickens lay again"
description: "Quake-rattled chickens lay again"

Author: "Ash, Julie"
Title: "Shaken quake refugee plans return"
description: "Shaken quake refugee plans return"

Author: "Easton, Paul"
Title: "Family move from tsunami to bombs, quake and floods"
description: "Family move from tsunami to bombs, quake and floods"

Author: "McCrone, John"
Title: "Who's in charge?"
description: "Queries who is leading the rebuilding effort of quake-damaged Canterbury. Wonders whether the effort is being driven by bureaucracy, or whether the complex behind-the-scenes process is the right path for a complicated problem. Talks to former Christchurch mayor Garry Moore, Christchurch East MP Lianne Dalziel, Christchurch mayor Bob Parker and Christchurch City Council chief executive Tony Marryatt and Minister of Earthquake Recovery Gerry Brownlee. Includes a graphic showing the agencies involved in the rebuilding of the region."

Author: "Booker, Jarrod"
Title: "'I was lucky' says worst-hit quake victim"
description: "'I was lucky' says worst-hit quake victim"

Author: "Wall, Tony"
Title: "The forgotten people"
description: "Focuses on the residents of Seabreeze Close in Christchurch, who continue to live like refugees in ruined homes a full five months after the Canterbury earthquake liquified their street. Stresses the growing anger at the lack of action over thier plight."

Author: "Cropp, Amanda,"
Title: "Blue chip blues"
description: "Reports on the efforts to save and restore some of Fendalton's beautiful character homes, which were hard hit bt the Canterbury earthquake."

Author: "Heather, Ben"
Title: "[Project Canterbury]"
description: "Recaps some of the most pressing problems facing Cantabrians and those charged with rebuilding the region after the major earthquake on 4 Sep 2010. Includes a timetable of meetings and other important events scheduled between 2011 and 2013. Touches on major rebuilding work under way. Reports on the demolition of the century-old Coptic Church. Overviews repair work to schools that has been completed or still to be done. Informs that a street barrier in Christchurch has been extended for public safety."

Author: "Booker, Jarrod"
Title: "Help in time of need for earthquake's victims"
description: "Help in time of need for earthquake's victims"

Author: "Gorman, Paul,"
Title: "Southern jitters"
description: "Reports in the wake of the September 2010 Christchurch earthquake Dunedin is taking a look at their own heritage buildings and how much they might lose if they were to experience a significant earthquake. Takes stock of the number of Historic Places Trust category one buildings, how many of those are earthquake strengthened, the number of heritage visitors that come to Dunedin and the economic benefit that brings. Assesses the likelihood of an earthquake in Dunedin considering the location of fault lines in the area and what the city has experienced so far. Comments on the current policy of Dunedin City Council with regard to earthquake strengthening of buildings."

Author: "Booker, Jarrod"
Title: "Aftershock adding to main quake damage"
description: "Aftershock adding to main quake damage"

Author: "Carroll, Joanne"
Title: "A helping hand leads to death for man on the way home"
description: "Tells of Owen Wright, one of many who passed away while trying to help others in the Christchurch earthquake."

Author: "Anstiss, Celeste Gorrell"
Title: "Quiet hero becomes a Facebook sensation"
description: "Tells of one of the heroes of the Christchurch earthquake."

Title: "Stories from the suburbs"
description: "Tells of the 12 suburbs in Christchurch surrounding Lyttelton and what affects the Christchurch earthquake has caused these towns. Suburbs include; Papanui, Avonhead, Yaldhurst, Sockburn, Templeton, Opawa, Shirley, Burwood, Southshore and Sumner."

Author: "Macfie, Rebecca"
Title: "Quake : 12.51, Tuesday, February 22, 2011; Fatal failure"
description: "Covers the effects of the devastating 6.3 magnitude earthquake, which has caused irrevocable damage and killed a substantial number of people, principally in the Central Business District. Ask why, concentrating on the CBD, did so many major buildings fall so catastrophically. Briefly profiles some of the stories of those who had close calls in the earthquake, and considers what long-lasting effects the ruination of Christchurch city will have on its residents."

Author: "Macfie, Rebecca"
Title: "Quake : 12.51, Tuesday, February 22, 2011; Fatal failure"
description: "Covers the effects of the devastating 6.3 magnitude earthquake, which has caused irrevocable damage and killed a substantial number of people, principally in the Central Business District. Asks why, concentrating on the CBD, did so many major buildings fall so catastrophically. Briefly profiles some of the stories of those who had close calls in the earthquake, and considers what long-lasting effects the ruination of Christchurch city will have on its residents."

Author: "Clifton, Jane,"
Title: "The bottom line"
description: "Looks at where the money is going to come from to fix Christchurch and how this will affect what happens. Suggests that taxpayers may question the policy of guaranteeing to restore the ground, asking instead whether to simply accept that some places are too unstable to be built on. Considers this in light of the Earthquake Commission being the only major insurer in the world to insure the ground beneath buildings affected by an earthquake."

Author: "Entwisle, Peter"
Title: "Paying the past its due"
description: "Offers advice about the preservation of Dunedin's old buildings, discussing who should do it and who should pay for it.  Notes that the topic of heritage buildings has beome timely in the wake of the Christchurch earthquake (September 4 2010) and the unassisted collapse of the part of the Barron Building in Rattray Street. Recaps Dunedin's record of destroying and preserving its historic buildings. Touches on the deficit in the recording of heritage buildings, mentioning the role of the Historic Places Trust."

Author: "Milne, Jonathan"
Title: "Brick by brick, we'll return"
description: "Tells of the Christchurch Cathedral collapsing under the earthquake, but has the hopes of locals and those who grew up in Canterbury to rebuild and restore the Cathedral."

Author: "Fisher, David"
Title: "Seconds to flee as six floors fall"
description: "Talks with Mary-Anne Jackson, one of the survivors working in the CTV building that collapsed in the Christchurch earthquake and took most of her colleagues."

Author: "McCormick, Gary,"
Title: "The city was the colour of death"
description: "Gives authors account of the Christchurch earthquake."

Author: "Woodham, Kerre"
Title: "Their spirit is strong"
description: "Gives authors recount of the day of the Christchurch earthquake (Feb 22 2011)."

Author: "Quigley, Sarah"
Title: "Quake pain felt in Berlin"
description: "Recounts the author's experience of watching news coverage of the earthquake via live internet streaming while living in Berlin."

Author: "Glionna, John M."
Title: "Uncle Bob, he's the everywhere mayor"
description: "Looks at the actions of the Christchurch mayor before and after the Feb 2011 earthquake, noting praise and criticism from NZers. Evaluates the effect of his work as a television host.  Touches on the earthquake's role in the city's mayoral race of 2010."

Author: "Gaynor, Brian"
Title: "Quake wake-up call for disaster insurer"
description: "Looks at the impact the Canterbury/Christchurch earthquakes may have on the Earthquake Commission (EQC) and its ability to insure future natural disasters."

Author: "Poole, Marian"
Title: "Kooky concert provides simple togetherness"
description: "Reviews performances in the Last Night of the Proms, 25 Feb 2011, Dunedin Town Hall, including a piece by Mayor Dave Cull and songs sung in recognition of the Feb 22 Christchurch earthquake."

Author: "Van Kempen, Lynda"
Title: "Art deco crowds respond to quake"
description: "Reports on the 11th Art Deco festival, held in Ranfurly Feb 2011, noting the special fundraising events held to assist people affected by the Christchurch earthquake."

Author: "De Reus, Helena"
Title: "'Quaky cat' being reprinted"
description: "Reports on plans to reprint the title by the Caitlin-based author that describes a cat's experience of an earthquake and is aimed at raising funds for the September 4 2010 and now the February 22 2011 earthquakes in the Christchurch region."

Author: "Clifton, Jane,"
Title: "As good as it gets"
description: "Comments on inevitable emotional outbursts by public figures following the earthquake. Posits homelessness as the major issue facing the Government, recapping the cover provided by most house insurance policies. Describes the process that must be followed before insurance companies can make payouts. Notes the unusual step that the Government may take regarding post-earthquake land restoration. Warns of the difficulty of governmental plans to spur growth while meeting the needs of people in Canterbury."

Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"
Title: "Hope and despair"
description: "Shares her experience of the earthquake and seeing the destruction of and around her home of 17 years. Visits the CBD and other parts of the city reporting on the sights and smells of post-earthquake Christchurch, including the good and humorous things that are also happening. Relays the issues of rebuilding, unemployment, and the possible lack of doctors to care for crush victims. Looks to the need for a sensible vision for the city for those who are destined to stay there."

Author: "Laugesen, Ruth"
Title: "Past tense"
description: "Discusses the debate on heritage versus safety in NZ, in the wake of buildings crumbling in the Canterbury earthquakes. Indicates how older and more recently built structures fared in the Feb 22 earthquake, including the Pyne Gould building and the ChristChurch Cathedral. Examines the purpose of earthquake strengthening and the requirements of the 2004 Building Act. Notes the safety status of post-earthquake buildings in Napier. Laments the cautiousness of authorities regarding earthquake-prone buildings. Speaks to councillors and heritage experts about the building code strength of structures in Wellington. Notes the number of unreinforced masonry buildings in NZ. Cites heritage specialists regarding the tradeoff between saftey, cost and heritage."

Author: "Black, Joanne"
Title: "Lessons from Kobe"
description: "Talks to University of British Columbia geography professor David Edgington about his research into reconstruction following the 1995 earthquake in Kobe, Japan, highlighting contrasts with and lessons for Christchurch. Advises of the need for speed and to provide long-term confidence for private sector rebuilding.  [Print exclusive]"

Author: "Meng-Yee, Carolyne"
Title: "Strength to lead city in the eye of a storm"
description: "Talks to the Christchurch mayoress about the response of the mayoral couple to the devastating earthquake."

Author: "Van Beynen, Martin"
Title: "Help from all directions [part 1]; Mayor to hold public meetings"
description: "Focuses on the effects of the earthquake on residents and businesses in the eastern suburbs. Informs that Mayor Bob Parker will address four open-air meeting in various parts of the eastern suburbs, 6 Mar 2011."

Author: "Fox, Michael"
Title: "Strength born of adversity and faith"
description: "Showcases the work being done by four of the front-line staff who are coordinating the relief and recovery operation and preparing the city to move forward after the devastating earthquake. Speaks to Christchurch City Council operations manager Peter McDonald, emergency operations centre manager Murray Sinclair, Christchurch City Council building evaluation manager Steve McCarthy and welfare team member Annette Purvis."

Author: "McCrone, John"
Title: "Signs of civil unrest"
description: "Concentrates on how grassroots organisations are beginning to make their presence felt in post-earthquake Christchurch. Talks to various community organisers about the potential for a grassroots approach to change the nature of local politics and community decision making."

Author: "Moore, Chris"
Title: "Simple steps to heal the mental scars"
description: "Offers advice to assist Cantabrians to recover from the psychological damage of the earthquakes. Seeks comment from Cerina Altenburg, team leader of the General Practice Mental Health Liaison Service, Christchurch."

Author: "Cumming, Geoffrey"
Title: "How to mend a shattered city from the ground up"
description: "Considers some of the factors to be taken into account when planning the reconstruction of Christchurch city, including being cautious about multi-storey buildings. Asserts that the experts need to understand why some areas and structures were harder hit than others. Looks at the issues that will form the basis of expert consideration on Christchurch's future, including siesmic gaps, lifelines, liquefaction and slips. Touches on domestic and commercial building types that fared better during the quake."

Author: "Holmes, Paul,"
Title: "Interpreter's magic hands speak to thousands"
description: "Praises the directive to have news coverage of the Christchurch earthquake translated into sign language, NZ's third official language. Extols the talents of Jeremy Borland, who has done much of the interpreting during television news items."

Author: "Davy, Ray"
Title: "One size doesn't fit all"
description: "Asserts that people who do not wish to remain in the city after the 22 Feb 2011 earthquake should have the option to do so. Comments on the challenges of rebuilding homes and remediating property and the policy approach that Government, the Christchurch City Council and the Earthquake Commission (EQC) should be taking to address these challenges."

Author: "Van den Bergh, Roeland"
Title: "All Kiwis counting the cost of quake with bigger premiums"
description: "Focuses on the role of insurance companies in rebuilding the commercial heart of the city and its residential suburbs after the 22 Feb 2011 earthquake. Seeks comment from Chris Ryan, chief executive of the Insurance Council, and others. Provides facts about the role and functions of the commission."

Author: "Newman, Liz"
Author (detailed): "/ as told to Liz Newman [and others]"
Title: "Kids' quake"
description: "Interviews six-year-old twins Grace Newman and Thomas Newman, sisters Lauren Sargent and Anna Sargent and brothers Timothy Cornell and Benjamin Cornell about their experiences of the earthquake, which struck while all were at school."

Author: "Van Beynen, Martin"
Title: "With a little help from our friends"
description: "Focuses on the residents of the eastern suburbs of Christchurch and what they are doing to help each other and the help that has arrived to improve their living conditions after the Christchurch February earthquake amongst which are lack of electricity, water, toilets and the problems associated with flooding and liquefaction."

Author: "Hembry, Owen"
Title: "Rebuilding Brand NZ; Urgent task to rebuild Brand NZ"
description: "Reports on the stress felt by the tourism industryas it tries to combat the inevitable negative effects of the Christchurch earthquake on tourism in NZ in the short term."

Author: "Anderson, Vicki"
Title: "Light years away"
description: "Talks to the Christchurch-raised musician about being apart from the Christchurch-based members of his family on the day of the earthquake. Discusses the process of making his new album, to be released at the Homegrown music festival, Wellington, 5 Mar 2011."

Author: "Killick, David,"
Title: "The clear necessities of life"
description: "Offers advice for coping at home in post-quake Christchurch, where potable water is scarce and toilets may be located outdoors."

Author: "Macdonald, Nikki"
Title: "Home will never be home again; Homes away from home"
description: "Looks at some people who have moved to another location outside Christchurch after experiencing the second earthquake in February 2011 and have decided not to return to Christchurch to live. Gauges the effect of this move, whether permanent or temporary on South Island towns who are accommodating the influx of people. Notes the short term influx of people is stretching housing, education, health and welfare services."

Author: "Macdonald, Nikki"
Title: "Influx of earthquakes refugees tests Timaru's resources"
description: "Reports that Timaru's population has swelled by 20%, from 27,000 to 33,000 with a flood of 6,000 Christchurch residents getting out of their shaken city. Questions how long will these people stay indicating it makes it difficult to plan in terms of school rolls, housing/accommodation and infrastructure."

Author: "Knight, Kim,"
Title: "Shockwaves will roll on"
description: "Examines the gamut of emotional, behavioural, physical and cognitive responses to emergency situations such as the 22 February earthquake, including the author's own experience as an Aucklander and ex-Christchurch resident. Provides advice from Auckland University associate professor of clinical psychology Ian Lambie."

Author: "Small, Vernon"
Title: "Quake rebuilding costs a big stretch in tough times"
description: "Considers how NZ will pay for the reconstruction of Christchurch when the estimated cost is $20 billion, particularly in hard financial times. Looks at forecasts from NZIER (New Zealand Institute of Economic Research) which indicate 'virtually no economic growth' and the closing of NZers wallets' to reduce debt. Forecasts higher costs for individuals and businesses along with a spike in unemployment. Notes in the short term there will be an injection of cash into the economy with money being released by EQC (Earthquake Commission) and overseas insurers along with an expected cut in the OCR (official cash rate) by 25 basis points. Includes an outline of where the author thinks the money is coming from and who is paying."

Author: "Chapman, Kate"
Title: "The rebuild : getting it right"
description: "Examines the issue of whether to turn Christchurch CBD into a flat, structureless green park and the businesses moved elsewhere. Notes in the last 200 years or so it has been rare for central governments to let their cities die. Discusses factors such as building practices, rebuilding of heritage buildings, stability of the ground and the materials that will be used if the decision is to reconstruct Christchurch. Includes the evolution of building standards."

Author: "Van den Bergh, Roeland"
Title: "Quake set to hit premiums; Scale of destruction means many will suffer because of long rebuild time"
description: "Examines the issue of insurance and earthquakes and the financial consequences for insurance companies and their reinsurers that have arisen as a result of the two catastrophic earthquakes that have severely damaged Christchurch and parts of Canterbury. Notes Chris Ryan (Insurance Council chief executive) is of the view that because reinsurance makes up a large part of insurance companies' costs he expects the increases in reinsurance prices will be passed on to customers through higher premiums. Notes the issue of people and corporations who are under insured and the consequences of having to wait a long time for houses and business premises to be rebuilt."

Author: "Ninness, Greg"
Title: "Auckland's quake fix go-slow"
description: "Examines the safety of Auckland buildings in the wake of the recent earthquake in Christchurch. Notifies of delays in risk assessment due to the super city amalgamation. Outlines the city's Earthquake Prone Buildings Policy. Compares the differing building policies of councils depending on the earthquake risk of the area they control. Notes the number of buildings considered by Auckland City Council to be at risk."

Author: "Head, Warren"
Title: "Disaster strikes at recovery"
description: "Assesses the current economic situation, given the likelihood of a 'double-dip' recession, the Pike River Mine and Christchurch earthquakes disasters and other economic factors. Seeks comment from several economists and economic analysts about whether the economy is improving or getting worse."

Author: "Fletcher, Richard"
Title: "Earthquake law - the debate continues; Earthquake update"
description: "Comments further on the current law being used to deal with the effects of the earthquake on 4 Sep 2010. Cites concern expressed by the Auckland District Law Society and other lawyers that the powers granted in the Act (CERRA) go further than any previous legislation, including the Public Safety Conservation Act 1932. Includes an update noting that this column was written before the more destructive earthquake of 22 Feb 2011."

Author: "Ireland, Kieran"
Author (detailed): "Kieran Ireland, Alex Lister and Brooke Roberts"
Title: "[Secondary scene : East Otago High School]; Martinborough moods a feast for the senses; Christchurch casualties not forgotten; A dark day"
description: "Features creative writing and art from four East Otago High School pupils, including observations of a visit to Martinborough, a report and a poem on the Christchurch earthquake, and artwork by Sarah Law about her holiday from Dunback to Wellington in early 2010."

Author: "Francis, Clio"
Title: "Into the breach"
description: "Profiles six people who have key roles in the aftermath of the earthquake. Talks to the coroner, the chief executive of energy company Orion NZ Ltd, the NZ Police Superintendent and night commander, the director of special operations for the Fire Service, the Civil Defence national controller and the Labour MP for Christchurch Central."

Author: "Francis, Clio"
Title: "Broad shoulders to carry city forward"
description: "Profiles six people who have key roles in the aftermath of the earthquake. Talks to the coroner, the chief executive of energy company Orion NZ Ltd, the NZ Police Superintendent and night commander, the director of special operations for the Fire Service, the Civil Defence national controller and the Labour MP for Christchurch Central."

Author: "Burgess, Dave"
Title: "Shuddering in Wellington; The Cuba St Quarter"
description: "Focuses on the concern surrounding the city's earthquake-prone buildings in light of the deadly 22 February 2011 Christchurch Earthquake. Talks to Wellington Mayor Celia Wade-Brown about the restrengthening timeframes for the city's earthquake-prone buildings. Looks at what makes a building earthquake-prone and what buildings are required to withstand. Presents a map of the earthquake-prone buildings in the Cuba Street area."

Author: "Todd, Rebecca"
Title: "Health service ready to help mentally scarred"
description: "Reports that health professionals in the region are preparing for an influx of people who will need help to cope with the trauma of the earthquakes. Seeks comment from Prof Mark Creamer, director of the Australian Centre for Post-Traumatic Mental Health, about the range of responses people have to disastrous events, and the importance of having fun to improve wellbeing. Cites remarks from Canterbury District Health Board chief of psychiatry Sue Nightingale. Talks to some people who survived the earthquake about how they are faring. Speaks to pharmacist Don Sache about the increase in demand for tranquillisers or sleeping pills."

Author: "Gorman, Paul,"
Title: "What's next?; Ring predictions play on fears"
description: "Asks earthquake experts for their assessment of whether a third big earthquake is likely, particularly given the existence of a previously hidden fault that ruptured on 26 Dec 2010, causing a magnitude 4.9 earthquake that caused significant damage to or weakening of buildings in the central business district. Notes the ethical and political difficulties for scientists in determining what information to impart and when. Talks to GNS Science natural hazards manager Dr Kelvin Berryman, visiting Pennsylvania State University geologist Prof Kevin Furlong and University of Canterbury geological sciences Prof Jarg Pettinga. Cites comment from Christchurch Mayor Bob Parker about the need for a thorough survey of geological hazards before considering a multibillion-dollar rebuild. Asks some of these people to comment on the prediction by Auckland weather forecaster Ken Ring of another major earthquake in the region on 20 Mar 2011."

Author: "De Bueger, John"
Title: "Lessons of hindsight in rebuild"
description: "Comments on the lessons that should be learned in rebuilding the central business district (CBD) of the city following the latest large earthquake on 22 Feb 2011. Recalls a reprint of an old colonial drawing showing the  landscape of the Canterbury Plains in the early 1850s, depicting low-lying swampland that later became the CBD. Notes that the areas worst affected by the earthquake are located in these old marshes. Offers advice to town planners in the city. Cautions that Hamilton and Whanganui also have similar landscapes so building codes should be updated."

Author: "Stewart, Tamlyn"
Title: "Tech firm brushes off quake"
description: "Showcases the visual-simulation specialist firm that is continuing to hire staff despite having to abandon its leased premises in the cordoned-off section of the central business district after the 22 Sep 2011 earthquake. Talks to company founder Sam Chaffey about its business activities in NZ and overseas."

Author: "Gadd, David"
Title: "Jo flees NZ quake for ordeal in Japan"
description: "Jo flees NZ quake for ordeal in Japan"

Author: "Wall, Tony"
Title: "Forgotten people are forgotten again"
description: "Follows the plight of Bexley residents in Seabreeze Close since September, the time of the first major earthquake to hit Christchurch. Reports they continue to live like refugees in ruined homes a full five months after the Canterbury earthquake liquified their street. Stresses the growing anger at the lack of action over thier plight."

Author: "Dudding, Adam"
Title: "Christchurch 2016; Beginner's guide to rebuilding; Welcome to our Christchurch; Voices from abroad"
description: "Looks at how Christchurch city is going to rebuild and recounts what happen in the case of Napier after the 1931 earthquake flattened the city. Notes the debate about the realities of knocking down buildings, whether repair is possible for some heritage buildings is growing and a decision about whether to build high or low also has to be made. Features comment from Norman Foster (British architect), Hank Dittmar (chief executive of Prince Charles's conservation minded Foundation for the Built Environment) and Simon Jenkins (UK journalist). Includes interviews of ten prominent NZers who give a wide range of personal views about what shape the city of Christchurch should take."

Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"
Title: "'We are just shattered'"
description: "Portrays life in Christchurch two weeks after the big quake hit it. Shows residents such as Brian Frisken (74, Bexley) and Barbara Kerr (Aranui) coping with living in the aftermath, and describes community support and efforts to recover. Discusses the problem of temporary housing with winter approaching."

Author: "Priestley, Rebecca,"
Title: "Aftershock zone"
description: "Discusses the state of earthquake prediction.  Looks at a Geonet model used by Matt Gerstenberger of GNS Science to show earthquake and aftershock probabilities in Canterbury, describing their use in wake of the recent pair of earthquakes and the possibility of the Alpine Fault triggering an even larger earthquake. Looks at the possible use of warning time given by an early warning system."

Author: "Easton, B. H."
Title: "Quakenomics"
description: "Discusses the pitfalls of the idea of 'GDP' (gross domestic product), looking at the effects of the Christchurch earthquake as an example."

Author: "White, Xanthe"
Title: "New shoots"
description: "Gives a personal account of being caught up in the earthquake in Christchurch while being involved with the Ellerslie Flower Show. Draws inspiration from Christchurch's image as a garden city."

Author: "Anderson, Vicki"
Title: "Big little girl band"
description: "Talks to Lisa Blatchford, bassist and vocalist for the Auckland-based trio that started in Christchurch as 'Starlett'. Backgrounds the work that has gone into their debut album, recorded in Los Angeles. Mentions what happened to her family after the 22 Feb 2011 earthquake."

Author: "Harris, Catherine"
Title: "Skilled in action; Firms look overseas amid looming skills shortage"
description: "Looks at the current skills shortage in NZ and what is being done to address it. Talks to the former world champion discus thrower, now the chief executive of Best Pasifika Leadership Academy, about her own  upskilling plan and the focus of the Academy. Seeks comment from others in the building, engineering, hospitality and IT sectors, as well as spokespersons from the recruitment and industry training sectors and ANZ chief economist Cameron Bagrie. Informs that construction and infrastructure firms are likely to form alliances with international companies to provide the skilled labour necessary to rebuild Christchurch."

Author: "Price, Mark"
Title: "Finding solid ground"
description: "Speaks to two families who have been displaced by the Christchurch earthquake about their plans for the future. Notes that the region has 'quietly absorbed' hundreds, and possibly thousands, of Christchurch residents, some of whom are likely to remain in Otago."

Author: "Masters, Catherine"
Title: "City unites on day of healing"
description: "Describes the service held in Hagley Park in memory of the February 22 2011 earthquake, featuring parts of speeches given by Mayor Bob Parker, Ngai Tahu elder Henare Rakiihia, and Prince William. Relays the experience of some of the families of those killed in the earthquake."

Author: "Barton, Chris"
Title: "Building on shaky ground"
description: "Explores the options being considered for rebuilding Christchurch after its two earthquakes. Describes the damage, the most prominent weaknesses, and restoration efforts, as they relate to the city's affected suburbs, hills, and CBD area. Raises questions about the destruction, restoration or rebuilding of heritage and central city buildings. Quotes the views of Compusoft Engineering director Barry Davidson on seismic engineering, lack of political will to enforce building standards, and the need to check engineer's designs. Illustrates a model of a resilient house designed by Copeland Associates Architects."

Author: "Pepperell, Susan"
Title: "The rise of the cake-stall nation"
description: "Talks to the head of the Christchurch Earthquake Appeal Mark Weldon about the funds raised so far. Touches on the effect of the earthquake and tsunami in Japan.  Names the three main funds to which people can contribute, and outlines what the money is being spent on."

Author: "Dudding, Adam"
Title: "Power struggle"
description: "Profiles the CEO of Orion about his role in restoring electricity to Christchurch after its earthquakes. Talks about his hero status in the city and his career in the electricity sector. Touches on his salary, famous family members and why he is an energy-conscious person."

Author: "Moore, Johnny"
Title: "Black Tuesday"
description: "Provides a diary of his days following the earthquake, starting at the Goodbye Blue Monday live music venue in Christchurch that he co-owns with his parents and siblings."

Author: "Mackenzie, Dene"
Title: "Interim 'villages' of units planned; Logistics of rehousing Christchurch will be daunting"
description: "Examines the tender document proposal from the Dept of Building and Housing for 'imminent' temporary accommodation in the city following the two earthquakes. Describes the three stages being assessed. Talks to Dunedin builders and Dunedin City Council economic development manager Peter Harris about the logistical difficulties of housing displaced Christchurch residents."

Author: "Price, Mark"
Title: "A ring of truth?"
description: "Focuses on the prediction by Auckland weather forecaster Ken Ring that Christchurch would experience another large earthquake on 20 Mar 2011. Talks to him about public reaction to his prediction, including death threats. Seeks comment from ACC Minister Nick Smith and several scientists who refute his methods and dismiss his predictions as misguided and irresponsible. Speaks to Victoria University psychologist Assoc Prof Marc Wilson about the results of his 2008 study into beliefs. Includes other tried but unproven ways of predicting the future."

Author: "Porteous, Debbie"
Title: "26 days later ..."
description: "Talks to local residents in Christchurch and Lyttelton to see how they are faring after the second major earthquake since 4 Sep 2010. Sums up the situation."

Author: "Birss, Neill"
Title: "Financing the rebuild"
description: "Looks at ways in which Christchurch can help pay its share of the bill for the February 22 earthquake."

Author: "Sharpe, Marty"
Title: "What Napier can teach Christchurch about rebuilding; Need for haste balanced with the need for preservation"
description: "Focuses on three lessons that Christchurch can learn from Napier, which recovered quickly after their city was ruined in a 7.9 magnitude earthquake, 3 Feb 1931. Cites an 1997 paper by economist Simon Chapple, estimating the economic impact of the Napier quake. Seeks comment on this paper from NZ Institute of Economic Research principal economist Shamubeel Eaqub, who emphasises the relevance of these findings to Christchurch. Speaks to Hawke's Bay museum and art gallery programmes leader Eloise Taylor, curator of an exhibition on the rebuilding of Napier. Talks to the retired architect who lived through the Feb 1931 earthquake, who comments on the situation and the parallels between the cities."

Author: "Jackson, Kerri"
Title: "The second course"
description: "Talks to the first winner of the Masterchef television cooking programme, Brett McGregor, about his experience of the Christchurch earthquakes and his first cookbook."

Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"
Title: "Blast those barricades"
description: "Portrays the frustration of Christchurch business owners whose CBD buildings have been barred by Civil Defence authorities, though journalists and dignitaries can participate in inner city guided tours. Talks to business owners - Gerald Westenra, David Collins, Joe Arts and Nicky Arts and Andrew Wheeley and Adele Wheeley - about how the ban has affected their businesses. Conveys criticism of and praise for the Canterbury Business Recovery service. Outlines plans for the central business district that are similar to those carried out in Napier after the 1931 earthquake."

Author: "Hutching, Chris"
Title: "Deja vu with a vengeance"
description: "Discusses the damaged caused to Christchurch after the Feb 2011 earthquake and estimates the cost to rebuild."

Author: "Booker, Jarrod"
Title: "Mum who lost family in quake wants to help"
description: "Mum who lost family in quake wants to help"

Author: "McCrone, John"
Title: "Ultimate makeover"
description: "Looks at earthquake damage in Christchurch. Assesses potential future hazards and design principles, including ideas about precincts, low rise blocks, parks, land ownership, car parking and urban villages.  Reveals University of Canterbury Vice-Chancellor Rod Carr's suggestion for developing Christchurch central. Emphasises the need for consultation on masterplans for rebuilding. Presents a debate over ways to stimulate commercial activity in the CBD, focusing on rent levels."

Author: "Matthews, Philip"
Title: "Treasured through the written word"
description: "Reflects on the role of writers in capturing memories of parts of the city that have been lost after the 22 Feb 2011 earthquake. Sums up a Kim Hill with the Christchurch-born and -raised author about 'the solace of art and literature', referring to several books about the city and the poems 'Pause' and 'Response' by Mary Ursula Bethell. Describes other books that have their settings in Christchurch after a telephone conversation with the author."

Author: "Matthews, Philip"
Title: "Act of God?"
description: "Investigates the devastating impact of the 4 Sep 2010 and 22 Feb 2011 earthquakes on churches in the city, and the questions and challenges now faced by clergy and congregations.  Speaks to Anglican Bishop of Christchurch Victoria Matthews, The Rev Lynda Patterson, Catholic Bishop of Christchurch Barry Jones and The Rev Martin Stewart."

Author: "Van Beynen, Martin"
Title: "Realism in the wake of the earthquake"
description: "Suggests, now that most services are running again in Christchurch, it may be time to focus on  achievements made since the earthquakes. Considers the effects of not holding World Cup rugby games in the city. Notes the differing ways in which community links are severed."

Author: "Laing, Sahera"
Title: "Tame the internal beast"
description: "Offers practical advice to Cantabrians on methods of getting the body back in balance to cope with the stress of the earthquakes and the constant aftershocks. Explains the role of adrenalin, serotonin, dopamine and endophins."

Author: "Steeman, Marta"
Title: "Quake a tale of two cities for business; Message to business; How does the end of the subsidy affect your business?"
description: "Reports on the status of businesses in the city as a result of the earthquake, based on a poll quoted this week by business leaders. Signals that the Government payroll and job loss subsidies package would be winding up. Lists key points made by Earthquake Recovery Minister Gerry Brownlee, Acting Minister of Economic Development David Carter, and Canterbury Employers Chamber of Commerce chief executive Peter Townsend. Talks to the owners of Switch Espresso, Pastel Shoe Dyers and Red Furniture about their situation."

Author: "Harris, Catherine"
Title: "Skilled in action; Firms look overseas for skills"
description: "Looks at the current skills shortage in NZ and what is being done to address it. Talks to the former world champion discus thrower Beatrice Faumuina, now the chief executive of Best Pasifika Leadership Academy, about her own upskilling plan and the focus of the Academy. Seeks comment from others in the building, engineering, hospitality and IT sectors, as well as spokespersons from the recruitment and industry training sectors and ANZ chief economist Cameron Bagrie. Informs that construction and infrastructure firms are likely to form alliances with international companies to provide the skilled labour necessary to rebuild Christchurch."

Author: "Dally, Joelle"
Title: "Tragic face of quake to be laid to rest; Baker who predicted shake a 'great guy' - colleague"
description: "Tragic face of quake to be laid to rest; Baker who predicted shake a 'great guy' - colleague"

Author: "Ensor, Blair"
Title: "Family lays 'face of the quake' to rest"
description: "Family lays 'face of the quake' to rest"

Author: "Hewitson, Michele"
Title: "Dick Scott"
description: "Talks to the historian, former journalist and communist who donated a Don Binney painting ('Kotare over the Ratana Church') to the Christchurch earthquake recovery, and which was subsequently actioned for $270,000, about his generosity and his writing."

Author: "Bradley, Lisa"
Title: "Bright lights, uncaring city"
description: "Considers whether Auckland has been less supportive than other areas of appeals to assist Christchurch after the latest  earthquake. Talks to John Paul Moss about his failed attempt to organise a charity concert in Auckland. Seeks comment from Christchurch comedian Gary McCormick about his views on assistance given to the city."

Author: "Hartevelt, John"
Title: "Democracy sidelined under Cera"
description: "Details the powers that the Cabinet has agreed to invest in the chief executive of Cera (Canterbury Earthquake Recovery Authority). Considers the effect of this relinquishing of control coming on the heels of the Government's sacking of Environment Canterbury in 2010.  Describes the development of an inner city earthquake recovery plan, led by the City Council, to which Christchurch residents will be able to contribute, as well a community forum, noting these fora will act as checks on Cera's power."

Author: "Harris, Catherine"
Title: "A policy of no tears after calamity; Beware of cheap insurance policies without first checking for 'fishhooks'"
description: "Investigates whether people can afford to be without insurance cover after the Christchurch earthquake. Talks to the Wairarapa woman whose rented house was destroyed by fire in 2006. Seeks views of Insurance Council chief executive Chris Ryan, Kapiti financial adviser Liz Koh, business development manager Terri Carrick and Insurance and Savings Ombudsman Karen Stevens. Discusses the relatively common practice among celebrities to insure body parts. Speaks to a specialist broker about the dearth of 'personal accident' insurance in NZ. Estimates 'multi-policy' insurance premiums for a hypothetical family of four living in Johnsonville."

Author: "De Lacy, Hugh"
Title: "Quake rocks retail revival"
description: "Assesses the effect on the retail trade of the 22 Feb earthquake in Christchurch. Seeks comment from Retailers Association chief executive John Albertson on his outlook for the retail sector.  Celebrates the rise in prices enjoyed in the dairy, wool and lamb sectors, and anticipates benefits for retail and hospitality sectors associated with the Football World Cup starting on 9 Sept."

Author: "Newton, Kate"
Title: "Learning to live with loss of a limb"
description: "Focuses on the relatively common procedure of limb amputation. Finds that every year nearly 400 people lose limbs, mainly because of vascular problems or diabetes. Talks about the physical and emotional impact of the loss on amputees with experts such as Karen Michalanney, a field officer for the Amputee Society of Wellington, and Philippa Williams, a physiotherapist at the Wellington Artificial Limb Centre. Speaks to double-amputee Ben Hekenui about how his life changed after losing his legs in a baling machine. Briefly explains how a lower leg is amputated. Mentions the case of Brian Coker who had both legs amputated to free him from rubble after the 22 February 2011 Christchurch earthquake."

Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"
Title: "Frustration grows"
description: "Criticises the government's response to the Christchurch earthquakes. Alleges that the Canterbury Earthquake Recovery Authority demonstrates a good example of how not to run a recovery. Stresses the need for the organisation to be flexible, open and capable of engaging with local community leaders. Highlights the plight of residents in the badly-hit eastern suburbs, some of whom are still waiting for running water to be restored."

Author: "Milsom, Viv"
Title: "'Christchurch needs a festival'"
description: "Asks the question 'Can he make the Christchurch Arts Festival work in 2011?' Having the experience of organising the Southern Lakes Festival of Colour for the past 15 years, Philip Tremewan, says 'Christchurch needs a festival now, more than ever'. Describes the option now facing the organisers with Christchurch being in an altered and damaged state after the September and February earthquakes. Indicates although the venues, final programme and timing will all remain up in the air, what seems certain is that Christchurch will have an arts festival in 2011."

Author: "Gilbert, Jo"
Title: "Quake refugees find haven in resort; Wanaka enchants Chch quake refugees"
description: "Covers the role Wanaka has played in settling families displaced by the 22 Feb 2011 earthquake, noting the effects on the town's resources and schools. Gives statistics for post-earthquake enrolment of Christchurch pupils in schools nationwide. Describes the experience of the Fitzgerald and Hanson families and asks if they will return to Christchurch."

Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"
Title: "Sam the man; Read all about it"
description: "Talks to Sam Johnson, the motivating force behind the Student Volunteer Army. Gives his background, noting his early leadership talent. Shows how he kicked off a student volunteer clean-up following the first Christchurch earthquake, 4 Sep 2010, including the ad-hoc organisation needed to deal with unexpected numbers. Relates his standing for local politics, setting the Student Volunteer Army (SVA) up on Facebook, and his immediate reaction to the 22 Feb 2011 quake. Looks at how the SVA organised itself with IT and texting and handled a better management structure, and looks at him being recruited to help in Japan. Describes how the Hyde family of Redcliff created the 'Redcliff InfoPoint' social media and information service in the wake of the Feb 2011 earthquake to help their community."

Author: "McCrone, John"
Title: "Can we fix it?"
description: "Delves into the issue of whether land in suburbs damaged by the 22 February 2011 earthquake is worth rebuilding on. Describes the geotechnical work being undertaken, and what will happen when the information is reported in mid-May. Notes the complicating factor of increased flood risk in certain areas.  Talks to Canterbury University expert Misko Cubrinski about liquefaction and lateral spreading. Itemises the questions on land remediation facing the Government once the geotechnical report is complete."

Author: "Pepperell, Susan"
Title: "Faces of the quake"
description: "Revisits Christchurch two months after the February earthquake and a number of people tell their story. Emma Howard and Chris Greenslade, Ray Rarere, Ian McLeod and Drina Sisarich, and Amo Perelini reveal how the earthquake affected them and what they have done since the 22nd February."

Author: "Catherall, Sarah"
Title: "For God's sake"
description: "Talks to the following NZers about faith, prayer, God, and religion: physical sciences professor and NZer of the Year Sir Paul Callaghan, Little Bushman vocalist Warren Maxwell, real estate worker Lynley Webster, Wellington mayor Celia Wade-Brown, Catholic archbishop John Dew, track and field record holder Hamish Carson, Christchurch mayor Bob Parker, and office administrator Mary Denton."

Author: "Heather, Ben"
Title: "Many lessons learnt, says post-quake boss"
description: "Learns the views of the Civil Defence national controller on his role and perceptions of his approach to the aftermath of the February 22 2011 earthquake in Christchurch. Covers his military career and how this background came to the fore in his control of the disaster. Shares lessons that other NZ councils and other countries could learn about disaster response."

Author: "Lynch, Keith"
Title: "Behind the lines"
description: "Describes the journalist's experience of reporting from within Christchurch's cordoned off area at Civil Defence headquarters after the February 22 2011 earthquake. Touches on the media briefings at the Art Gallery, the international media, bus tours of the city centre, the visit by Prince William, and other impressions of the earthquake affected central business district."

Author: "Heather, Ben"
Title: "Quake chief bows out : 'I think I've done my bit'"
description: "Learns the views of the Civil Defence national controller on his role and perceptions of his approach to the aftermath of the February 22 2011 earthquake in Christchurch. Covers his military career and how this background came to the fore in his control of the disaster. Shares lessons that other NZ councils and other countries could learn about disaster response."

Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"
Title: "One day at a time"
description: "Reports on Christchurch's continuing crisis post-earthquakes, emphasising vanishing jobs and massive skills shortages. Highlights how entire sectors, including the tourism and foreign education markets, are in free-fall, while the real estate market is barely alive. Talks about various projects being set up to rebuild the workforce in Christchurch, particularly in the construction industry."

Author: "Laugesen, Ruth"
Title: "The power of one"
description: "Considers the abilities and qualities of the man in charge of the Canterbury Earthquake Recovery Authority (CERA) and the $8 billion rebuild of Christchurch. Looks back on his family background, childhood and career. Touches on his vision for how many of the city's icon heritage buildings should be restored."

Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"
Title: "Citizens onside"
description: "Talks to Conal McFeely, who runs Creggan Enterprises (a community economic development organisation in one of Londonderry's poorest suburbs), about how the rebuilding of strife-torn Londonderry can hold lessons for quake-ravished Christchurch."

Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"
Title: "Christchurch citizens onside"
description: "Talks to Conal McFeely, who runs Creggan Enterprises (a community economic development organisation in one of Londonderry's poorest suburbs), about how the rebuilding of strife-torn Londonderry can hold lessons for quake-ravished Christchurch."

Author: "Macdonald, Nikki"
Title: "How a quake-devastated community rebuilt itself; Rebuilding after the big one; Picking up and getting on with life [part 1]"
description: "Visits the California town devastated by the 6.9 Loma Prieta earthquake, 17 Oct 1989. Accompanies representatives of the Canterbury Chamber of Commerce to learn about how the town recovered over time, and lessons for NZ in the aftermath of the Canterbury earthquakes. Talks to several members of the business community, including a man whose two workmates died in the rubble of their coffee roasting business, and to a man whose independent bookshop was tagged as unsafe but whose business was saved by volunteer community labour. Speaks to the city planner and city manager about the rebuilding process. Talks to construction magnate Barry Swenson, who developed properties in Santa Cruz and who owns properties in NZ, including the earthquake-damaged Red Lion Hotel, Rangiora. Tells the stories of two women who were injured in the Santa Cruz earthquake. Briefly compares the California and 22 Feb 2011 Christchurch earthquakes. Includes a redevelopment timeline for the Santa Cruz community from 1989-1995."

Author: "Booker, Jarrod"
Title: "Shot, home lost in quake but cop finds hope in hard times: six months after being attacked at a siege in Christchurch an officer has returned to work"
description: "Shot, home lost in quake but cop finds hope in hard times: six months after being attacked at a siege in Christchurch an officer has returned to work"

Author: "Crean, Mike"
Title: "Quake news too much for former journalist"
description: "Quake news too much for former journalist"

Author: "Mackenzie, Dene"
Title: "Getting back to business after the big one"
description: "Speaks to Gen-i South Island sales manager Paul Deavoll about the aftermath of the 22 Feb 2011 earthquake on his business and staff. Describes his role in helping to keep Christchurch online."

Author: "Cumming, Geoffrey"
Title: "A test of character"
description: "Investigates the complacency surrounding the earthquake risk-management of older, unreinforced masonry buildings and the difficult questions the Canterbury earthquakes have raised for communities and councils around the country. Speaks to a number of engineers and heritage advocates about the issue and the various options for councils. Focuses on the situation in Auckland. Talks to building owners about their reaction to an incomplete Auckland Council list of around 400 pre-1940s buildings in the old Auckland City area which desktop analysis suggests may be below the 33 per cent of the design level threshold a new building must achieve to withstand a moderate earthquake. Discusses the option of retrofitting to strengthen at-risk older buildings, which is also recommended for reinforced concrete structures built from the 1940s to 1976."

Author: "Cole, Dennis"
Title: "High tech homing signal a godsend"
description: "Reports that missing pets that are microchipped and registered with the National Companion Animal Register can be returned to owners faster, and more often than pets that are not chipped. Notes that 85 percent of chipped pets missing after the 22 February Christchurch earthquake were returned, compared with 20-25 percent of unchipped pets."

Author: "Macdonald, Nikki"
Title: "A disaster's silver lining; Before complacency creeps in; Case study : bracing Berkeley; Liquefaction : when the ground turns to mush [part 3]"
description: "Looks at how the 6.9 magnitude Loma Prieta earthquake that struck San Francisco in 1989 provided the city with an unexpected opportunity to transform its disused waterfront, which had been cut off from the city by the double-decker Embarcadero Freeway. Focuses on San Francisco's efforts to improve diaster preparedness after the earthquake. Speaks to building inspector Laurence Kronfield who pioneered the coloured tag building system that was used in Christchurch after the Canterbury earthquakes. Mentions some of the recommendations from the Building Inspection Department's 'Community Action Plan for Seismic Safety' (CAPSS), which was set up to rank the most dangerous buildings and formulate a plan to make them safer. Spotlights the University of California's earthquake-strengthening project at its Berkeley campus. Talks about the liquefaction that occurred in San Francisco's Marina district during the earthquake. Touches on some ground improvement techniques to limit liquefaction risks."

Author: "Fisher, David"
Title: "Quake shakes foundations of couple's 28-year marriage"
description: "Quake shakes foundations of couple's 28-year marriage"

Author: "Van Beynen, Martin"
Title: "Residents continue to tough it out but now they need some answers"
description: "Looks at the situation of various families three months on from the Christchurch earthquake. Indicate they live in some of the worst hit areas in Christchurch, the eastern suburbs. Reports the residents are awaiting decisions from the Christchurch City Council and EQC (Earthquake Commission) with regard land and homes before they make firm decisions about their own plans. Notes what is working and what is not working in the eastern suburbs, how they are coping and what the residents want to happen next."

Author: "Cunliffe, Simon"
Title: "Feeling the ache of infinite distance; Absconder"
description: "Pays tribute to the late University of Otago graduate, former poetry contributor and newly qualified journalist, who perished in the CTV building in the Christchurch earthquake, 22 Feb 2011. Seeks comment from Dr Jacob Edmond and Dr Emma Neale about his contributions to the English Department at the university. Republishes a poem he wrote for the 'Monday's Poem' column, including some commentary from his mother, Fran Brookbanks."

Author: "Bowron, Jane,"
Title: "Columnist back in her home city with Old Bucky"
description: "Tells of the moments immediately after the Christchurch earthquake (Old Bucky) and getting back to her own home to find it severely damaged. Reflects on living within the 'Red Zone' and on her decision to return to Christchurch to look after her ageing parents along with the force of nature."

Author: "Atkinson, Coral"
Title: "Shreds of life hang in red-stickered houses"
description: "Notes many people are grieving at the loss of buildings, former old homes to the Christchurch earthquake."

Author: "Mackenzie, Dene"
Title: "[Budget 2011]"
description: "Reports on aspects of the Budget presented by Government, 19 May 2011. Sums up changes to the KiwiSaver and Working for Families schemes. Touches on the new Earthquake Kiwi Bond to help fund rebuilding in Christchurch, a rise in infrastructure spending, increased funding for dementia care, health funding, sale of state assets and debt reduction. Overviews changes to the student loan scheme, and increased funding for domestic medical students, community law centres and early childhood education. Includes reaction from residents in the region and from national commentators."

Author: "Gould, Bryan"
Title: "City's heritage another casualty of quake"
description: "City's heritage another casualty of quake"

Author: "Richter, Anke"
Title: "Auf the Richter scale"
description: "Reflects on cultural clashes after the German born author returned from a book tour of Germany and talks about how the Christchurch earthquake influenced her mental attitude and state. Describes how she managed the book tour while having left her family and devastated home and the people of Christchurch and Lyttelton back in NZ."

Author: "Dixon, Greg"
Title: "The long way home"
description: "Speaks to the two Los Angeles-based actors about being NZers overseas and why they are lending their support to the 22 May 'Rise up Christchurch' telethon to raise funds for the New Zealand Government's Christchurch Earthquake Appeal. Talks about their acting careers."

Author: "Brett, Cate"
Title: "Sticking together"
description: "Tells the story of the first 90 days since the 2011 Christchurch earthquake, as experienced by a Port Hills community. Describes the use of the internet to exchange information, the forming of groups to fill hillside cracks with bentonite under the guidance of resident Mara Apse, and the enjoyment of a community tango"

Author: "Wall, Tony"
Title: "Hard lessons"
description: "Talks to Shirley Boys' High School principal, John Laurenson, about his school's having to relocate to Papanui High School. Notes his response to being too tough on his students. Finds out if the influx of 1500 boys has had any effect on Papanui's female students. Talks to a student and a teacher about the day to day reality of campus sharing. Relays the principal's dreams for rebuilding the school. Briefly discusses the issues around and the schools involved in sharing campuses in Christchurch."

Author: "McKay, John"
Author (detailed): "John McKay, John Knight and Jo Appleyard"
Title: "Hurricanes, quakes and business interruption insurance"
description: "Highlights the UK High Court's decision in the case of 'Orient Express Hotels vs Generali Global Risk' over an insurance dispute arising from the hurricane damage to New Orleans in 2005 to explain the business interruption (BI) clause in an insurance policy."

Author: "Clifton, Jane,"
Title: "Crisis, what crisis?"
