description: "Covers the debate over the credibility of the 2011 Budget. Sums up the following areas of concern: doubt over revenue forecasts; cost of the Christchurch earthquake; lack of strategy; limited wage growth; unreliable overseas markets; national debt; household debt reduction; and a high NZ dollar. Looks at changes to Working for Families. Sums up the pros and cons of changes to the KiwiSaver scheme, citing comments by analysts Bernard Hickey, Mary Holm and Shamubeel Eaqub."

Author: "Clifton, Jane,"
Title: "2011 Budget - enough to avert economic crisis?"
description: "Covers the debate over the credibility of the 2011 Budget. Sums up the following areas of concern: doubt over revenue forecasts; cost of the Christchurch earthquake; lack of strategy; limited wage growth; unreliable overseas markets; national debt; household debt reduction; and a high NZ dollar. Looks at changes to Working for Families. Sums up the pros and cons of changes to the KiwiSaver scheme, citing comments by analysts Bernard Hickey, Mary Holm and Shamubeel Eaqub."

Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"
Title: "Giving Christchurch back its heart"
description: "Records the volume of suggestions for rebuilding Christchurch, including from such overseas organisations as the global conference movement TED. Contrasts this with the difficulties, particularly access rights, faced by CBD building owners. Talks to owners Dean Marshall and Lisle Hood about concerns over emotional and financial reserves, higher than anticipated insurance costs, more exacting building codes, and finding tenants. Cites a property developer's suggestions about using the opportunity to revive the CBD by avoiding malls and office 'parks', and issuing bonds to retail investors. Describes the comments of urban designer James Lunday on rebuilding an urban space that people want to live in."

Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"
Title: "Rebuilding Christchuch - the going gets tough"
description: "Records the volume of suggestions for rebuilding Christchurch, including from such overseas organisations as the global conference movement TED. Contrasts this with the difficulties, particularly access rights, faced by CBD building owners. Talks to owners Dean Marshall and Lisle Hood about concerns over emotional and financial reserves, higher than anticipated insurance costs, more exacting building codes, and finding tenants. Cites a property developer's suggestions about using the opportunity to revive the CBD by avoiding malls and office 'parks', and issuing bonds to retail investors. Describes the comments of urban designer James Lunday on rebuilding an urban space that people want to live in."

Author: "Ensor, Blair"
Title: "Kaikoura funeral for global symbol of earthquake"
description: "Kaikoura funeral for global symbol of earthquake"

Author: "Eleven, Beck"
Title: "Boulevard of broken dreams"
description: "Wonders if the Christchurch earthquakes have driven away retailers from High Street, and what might entice them to return. Talks to business owners, shoppers, urban designers, and landlords about the heritage buildings, the fashion boutiques, the low rents and the mix of creative people that made the area special. Notes some owners have relocated out of Christchurch. Cites comments by  C1 Expresso cafe owner Steve Crofsky about the organic growth of the area."

Author: "Croot, James"
Title: "Screen shot"
description: "Gauges the effect of the Christchurch earthquakes on the city's cinemas. Seeks explanation for the differences in theatre-going between Wellington and Christchurch, noting the latter's lack of a suitable venue for film festivals or arthouse cinema. Talks to movie enthusiasts about the possibility of restoring the Odeon or the Isaac Theatre Royal.  Contains a short description of the Roxy Cinema in Miramar, restored to art deco opulence from its origins as the Capitol Theatre."

Author: "Todd, Rebecca"
Title: "Living and giving for those who died"
description: "Reports on a trip to Kobe, Japan,  to evaluate how its citizens coped with the 1995 Hanshin earthquake. Talks to Misako Matsuura and Kiyoshi Matusuura, whose son died in the quake, about the volunteer group Hands they formed for survivors and visitors to the city. Emphasises the importance of resettling people in community groups and of monitoring mental health. Discusses post traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) with Japanese psychologist Tomoko Osawa who visited NZ after the 22 Feb Christchurch earthquake."

Author: "Matthews, Philip"
Title: "The view from the cordon"
description: "Reflects on the sights seen on a three-hour remembrance walk around the cordon surrounding Christchurch's earthquake damaged CBD. Starts at the Colombo and St Asaph street intersection, noting the condition of various buildings, the signs people have put up, and the feelings this 'disaster tourism' evokes."

Author: "McCrone, John"
Title: "Police, in numbers, reassure citizens on shattered streets of Christchurch"
description: "Investigates crime patterns emerging following the relatively law abiding days following the 22 Feb Christchurch earthquake. Accompanies two out-of-town police officers on a 'trust and reasssurance' patrol around the city. Talks to Superintendent Andy McGregor about policing immediately after the earthquake, the effects of alcohol, and the anticipated effects of stress and hardship in the long term."

Author: "Booker, Jarrod"
Title: "Wedding bells ring for quake amputee"
description: "Wedding bells ring for quake amputee"

Author: "Tapaleao, Vaimoana"
Title: "Pilot was to help in quake work"
description: "Pilot was to help in quake work"

Author: "Smith, Charmian"
Title: "Show goes on, despite quake; The show goes on"
description: "Spotlights the planning of the play 'Five women wearing the same dress', a collaborative production between the Fortune Theatre and the Court Theatre. Talks to Fortune Theatre artistic director Lara Macgregor about the decision to move the production from Christchurch to Dunedin after the 22 Feb 2011 earthquake. Informs of its season at the Fortune Theatre, Dunedin, 3-25 Jun 2011, followed by a run at the Aurora Theatre, Christchurch."

Title: "Teen shot by cops had recently fled quake city"
description: "Teen shot by cops had recently fled quake city"

Author: "Cairns, Lois"
Title: "Invisible scars of quake trauma"
description: "Discusses the post-earthquake mental issues that are affecting many Christchurch residents. Details the post-disaster relaxation techniques taught by US psychologist Dr James Gordon, and his desire to work in Christchurch. Relays a Christchurch woman's experience of being unable to cope. Documents the ongoing need for counselling in the city, citing the most common mental health problems people are facing. Talks to David Beaumont whose son died in the CTV building about his healing process."

Author: "Brownlee, Gerry,"
Title: "Robust decisions on rebuilding vital for all landowners; How best to deliver the bad news?"
description: "Explains the process behind some of the big decisions to be made on the future of some Christchurch land. Notes where the damage delivered by the September 4 (2010) earthquake was able to be fixed by relatively modest civil works, the February 22 (2011) quake has caused much of the work that was under way to be reconsidered and presents a host of far greater engineering challenges. Includes maps that show the difference in scale between the two events. Includes comment from Vernon Small The Press national affairs editor."

Author: "Matthews, Philip"
Title: "UC : university challenge; In the school of hard knocks"
description: "Investigates the seriousness of the disruption to Canterbury University caused by the Canterbury and Christchurch earthquakes. Reveals the details of the damage to various building on the campus and the likely solutions once all the assessments have been completed. Debates the likelihood the site of the university campus will change. Assesses the number of students the university has lost and how many are likely to return either in term 2 or next year. Describes how students have managed to cope with the disruption, missing out on classes, having classes in different venues and helping out the citizens of Christchurch to remove the debris caused by the liquefaction."

Author: "Todd, Rebecca"
Title: "Fear factor keeps students away"
description: "Investigates the long-term impacts on Christchurch's multimillion dollar international student market caused by the earthquakes in Christchurch and Canterbury."

Author: "Eleven, Beck"
Title: "Christchurch gets its man"
description: "Reports that Roger Sutton takes on the helm of Canterbury Earthquake Recovery Authority (Cera) and the positive response he has received by the residents of Christchurch. Details his schooling and his interest in mountain trekking, which his wife has experienced. Assesses the suitability of Roger Sutton to carry out the onerous task of organising the rebuilding of Christchurch and describes what he brings to the position as a person."

Author: "McCrone, John"
Title: "Please Mother Nature, are we halfway there yet?"
description: "Asks, after three big earthquakes in the city, what the odds are of a fourth one. Speaks to a number of scientists, including Kelvin Berryman of GNS Science and Professor Jarg Pettinga, head of geological science at Canterbury University, about assessing the hazard of more large earthquakes. Talks about the 6.3 magnitude earthquake that occurred on Monday 13 June 2011."

Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"
Title: "Writing from the edge"
description: "Describes how the relentlessness of the Christchurch earthquakes and the frustration of waiting for insurance companies to make decisions are taking its toll on the residents there."

Author: "McCrone, John"
Title: "A rubbish week"
description: "Asks, after three big earthquakes in the city, what the odds are of a fourth one. Speaks to a number of scientists, including Kelvin Berryman of GNS Science and Professor Jarg Pettinga, head of geological science at Canterbury University, about assessing the hazard of more large earthquakes. Talks about the 6.3 magnitude earthquake that occurred on Monday 13 June 2011."

Author: "Anderson, Vicki"
Title: "Danger in the air?"
description: "Looks at the 15-year battle to have the high-frequency radio mast at Ouruhia, near Bottle Lake, removed because of concerns about its electromagnetic field. Speaks to former Ouruhia resident Penny Hargreaves about the issue and her fight to get the case heard in the High Court. Highlights the recent warning issued by the World Health Organisation that radiofrequency electromagnetic fields could cause cancer. Talks about NZ's approach to the issue, including the NZ standard. Reports on the case of former Ouruhia resident Jan Zervos who believes she developed a tumour on her uterus because of the electromagnetic radiation emitted from the mast. Notes that the 151-metre Radio Network tower was recently removed, after being seriously damaged in the recent series of earthquakes in Canterbury, and replaced with a 25-metre tower for Civil Defence."

Author: "Cairns, Lois"
Title: "Battered residents just want out"
description: "Cites a poll showing the number of Christchurch residents wanting to leave the city, following the 6.3 magnitude earthquake that occurred on Monday 13 June 2011. Talks to residents of Liggins Street, Burwood, about the liquefaction, waiting for official word on their homes, neighbours who have left, and the psychological toll. Anticipates a Government announcement on which areas of Christchurch will need to be abandoned."

Title: "Reflecting on 150 years : 1888"
description: "Looks at news and events as they were recorded by the newspaper in 1888. Reports in the 8 May edition about a public meeting to protest against 'an influx of Chinese into the colony', Princess Theatre, Dunedin, 7 May 1888. Describes the effects in Invercargill and Christchurch of a violent earthquake on 1 Sep felt in the South Island, 3 Sep 1888. Publishes the text of a letter to the editor about a sweatshop in Dunedin, and the reply from the editor after investigating the situation, 20 Oct 1888. Includes a photograph of the Sew Hoy dredge owned by the Shotover Big Beach Gold Mining Co."

Author: "Cronshaw, Tim"
Title: "'Rob put himself at risk of being killed - he saved at least three people'"
description: "Recounts the bravery of the Canterbury dairy farmer who crawled into the Payne Gould Corporation (PGC) building in Christchurch to rescue people after the 22 Feb 2011 earthquake. Cites his comments about the courage of those waiting to be saved, and the comments of some of the people he saved. Mentions the reaction of his wife Debbie Mackle to his being in the collapsed building. Notes his feelings on the demolition of the city's damaged buildings."

Author: "Knox, Johanna"
Title: "When money is time"
description: "Explains the concept of a community time bank and community currency. Talks to Project Lyttelton chairwoman Margaret Jefferies about the town's six year old time bank initiative and how it helped in the aftermath of the recent earthquakes. Describes its origin as NZ's first time bank and how it has been used as a template for others in Kaitaia, Whakatane, Otaki, Gore and two suburbs in Christchurch. Compares the community building banks to local exchange trading systems (Lets), or green dollar schemes. Examines the currencies and organisation of Lets schemes in the Wairarapa, Golden Bay, and Whanganui. Also looks at the Out of our own backyards (Ooooby) organisation for trading homegrown produce, and the Local origin Ashhurst voluntary exchange (Loaves)."

Author: "Catherall, Sarah"
Title: "The shape crusader"
description: "Features houses in Queenstown and Auckland designed by the South African born architect, looking at their uniform cladding and noting that they concern some neighbours. Cites his views about rebuilding earthquake damaged Christchurch."

Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"
Title: "Shaky start"
description: "Interviews EQC chief executive officer Ian Simpson. Responds to criticisms that the Commission is not responding quickly enough to Christchurch earthquake claims."

Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"
Title: "Ian Simpson interview"
description: "Interviews EQC chief executive officer Ian Simpson. Responds to criticisms that the Commission is not responding quickly enough to Christchurch earthquake claims."

Author: "Cronshaw, Tim"
Title: "Cold sweat; Life-saver put aside his fears"
description: "Recounts the bravery of the Canterbury dairy farmer who crawled into the Payne Gould Corporation (PGC) building in Christchurch to rescue people after the 22 Feb 2011 earthquake. Cites his comments about the courage of those waiting to be saved, and the comments of some of the people he saved. Mentions the reaction of his wife Debbie Mackle to his being in the collapsed building. Notes his feelings on the demolition of the city's damaged buildings."

Author: "Booker, Jarrod"
Title: "Parents' burden lifted as quake victim identified"
description: "Parents' burden lifted as quake victim identified"

Author: "McCrone, John"
Title: "Relish the power of a new generation"
description: "Muses on different styles of political activism of baby boomers and Generation Y youth. Exemplifies the latter, describing the formation of the Student Volunteer Army (Sam Johnson), the Rebuild Christchurch website (Deon Swiggs),  the TEDxChChEQ conference (YChCh, Raf Manji), and the White Elephant Trust (Ant Rohan).  Cites examples where city council consultation with youth has not been fruitful. Reports on the US generated 2006 Cone Millenial Cause Study that sets out the characteristics of baby boomers, Generation X and Generation Y, noting the optimism and social entrepreneurship of the latter. Talks to Canterbury University Vice Chancellor Rod Carr about the need to adapt to and nourish the collaborative and active style of Gen Y."

Author: "Williams, David"
Title: "Piecing together a life"
description: "Talks to a Christchurch woman whose mother died in the 22 Feb 2011earthquake. Describes her experience of hearing details about her mother's death at the inquest for those who died in the collapsed CTV building just when the 13 Jun 2011earthquake struck. Remembers her mother and recalls the encouraging words of Prince William on showing him a photograph of her. Contains biographical material."

Author: "Jackson, Greg"
Title: "Earthquakes rekindle community bonds"
description: "Explains how emergency aid operations began after the Christchurch earthquakes. Lists the NGO 's Disaster Relief Forum (NDRF) members  in Christchurch and how they worked together with international and official organisations and community led groups. Gives examples of multiple organisations collaborating successfully with community groups, such as Rotary and the Salvation Army. Cites comments by international disaster rebuild expert Peter Kenyon on Christchurch's post-quake response."

Author: "Gillies, Abby"
Title: "City's people rocked to core and living on the edge"
description: "Having left Christchurch after the first earthquake in September the author returns after the February 22nd quake and finds most of her old haunts have been irreparably damaged or flattened completely. Visits the eastern suburbs where residents relate their feelings and plans for the future."

Author: "Knox, Johanna"
Title: "When money is time"
description: "Explains the concept of a community time bank and community currency. Talks to Project Lyttelton chairwoman Margaret Jefferies about the town's six year old time bank initiative and how it helped in the aftermath of the recent earthquakes. Describes its origin as NZ's first time bank and how it has been used as a template for others in Kaitaia, Whakatane, Otaki, Gore and two suburbs in Christchurch. Compares the community building banks to local exchange trading systems (Lets), or green dollar schemes. Examines the currencies and organisation of Lets schemes in the Wairarapa, Golden Bay, and Whanganui. Also looks at the Out of our own backyards (Ooooby) organisation for trading homegrown produce, and the Local origin Ashhurst voluntary exchange (Loaves)."

Author: "Catherall, Sarah"
Title: "The shape crusader"
description: "Features houses in Queenstown and Auckland designed by the South African born architect, looking at their uniform cladding and noting that they concern some neighbours. Cites his views about rebuilding earthquake damaged Christchurch."

Author: "Collins, Simon"
Title: "Survivors of the exodus"
description: "Describes how life has been for Christchurch families who moved to Auckland following the 2010-2011 earthquakes, talking to Brian Haybittle who resettled his family to the North Shore. Estimates the net loss of population from Christchurch, providing a breakdown of numbers for different groups: school children, international and language students, university students, rest home residents, Housing NZ tenants, beneficiaries and superannuitants. Also gives figures and destinations for Christchurch residents who left NZ. Forecasts the numbers expected to move to Christchurch to participate in rebuilding the city."

Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"
Title: "Hard yards"
description: "Looks at the circumstances of three households, Brian Frisken's from Bexley, Tim Stephenson's from Kairaki Beach and Steve and Marie Davies' from Kaiapoi, after the Government announced its package for Canterbury homeowners with earthquake damaged land."

Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"
Title: "The plight of Canterbury homeowners"
description: "Looks at the circumstances of three households, Brian Frisken's from Bexley, Tim Stephenson's from Kairaki Beach and Steve and Marie Davies' from Kaiapoi, after the Government announced its package for Canterbury homeowners with earthquake damaged land."

Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"
Title: "Christchurch is struck again"
description: "Describes how the relentlessness of the Christchurch earthquakes and the frustration of waiting for insurance companies to make decisions are taking its toll on the residents there."

Author: "Hutching, Chris"
Title: "Caution in most residential markets; More earthquake fallout"
description: "Advises of the prevailing mood reflected in sales volumes and prices in the residential real estate market, drawing on a joint BNZ and Real Estate Institute survey of licensed real estate agents nationwide.  Gauges the effect on insurance of the latest 13 Jun earthquake in Christchurch. Looks at the issue of what makes a building 'untenable', focusing on attempts by FM Custodians to cancel leases held by GP 96."

Author: "Matthews, Philip"
Title: "Visions of Avon's future"
description: "Looks at the argument to turn the city's earthquake devastated eastern residential areas around the Avon River into a park. Speaks to freelance writer Ashley Campbell about her idea for an 'Avon River Park' and to landscape architect Di Lucas about her approach to the idea. Talks about the social media debate it has inspired and the negative response from Earthquake Recovery minister Gerry Brownlee to the plans."

Author: "McCrone, John"
Title: "A rattle along for Ngai Tahu's legacy"
description: "Focuses on the growing involvement of Ngai Tahu in the affairs of Canterbury. Reports that, with the scale of rebuilding being demanded in response to the Canterbury earthquakes, Ngai Tahu is set to become an even greater influence. Suggests that it is making some people nervous. Speaks to Ngai Tahu's kaiwhakahaere (tribe chairman) Mark Solomon about why forging a bicultural identity is important for the future of the region and the country as a whole, pointing out that demographic figures suggest NZ's future is 'increasingly brown'. Talks about the internal battles within its tribal ruling body Te Runanga o Ngai Tahu (Tront) and its commercial operation Ngai Tahu Holdings. Looks at how Ngai Tahu is using its 1998 $170 million Treaty of Waitangi settlement to give its people a hand up, not a hand out, and how it has been driving the national agenda through pressure groups like the Iwi Leaders Forum, which represents the views of 57 iwi to Government. Speaks to Sacha McMeeking, the tribe's general manager of strategy and influence, about the letdown Maori are feeling over the way the Treaty of Waitangi has gone."

Author: "Hannan, Hayley"
Title: "Sir Peter Blake Leadership Awards"
description: "Honours the winners of the annual Sir Peter Blake Leadership Awards. Profiles the winner of the special award, student Sam Johnson, who organised the Student Volunteer Army clean up team following earthquakes in Christchurch; supreme award winner, public servant Dame Margaret Bazley; and 6 emerging leaders selected as showing great potential. Lists all supreme award winners since 2005."

Title: "Shot son's flight spurred by big-quake prediction"
description: "Shot son's flight spurred by big-quake prediction"

Title: "Quake's shock brings web team back to basics"
description: "Quake's shock brings web team back to basics"

Author: "Parsons-King, Amy"
Title: "Boutique on safer ground"
description: "Talks to the fashion designer who has relocated her boutique to her hometown after her business was destroyed in the Christchurch earthquake, 22 Feb 2011. Remarks on the tragedy of that day, which also claimed the life of her friend, Jillian Murphy, who was with her in the shop. Discusses her upbringing and career to date, and some of the labels she carries."

Author: "Cleaver, Dylan"
Title: "Against all odds, team carry the torch for their city; The final crusade"
description: "Looks at how the team reconfigured their 2011 Super 15 rugby season after the 22 February earthquake devastated Christchurch and their home ground, AMI Stadium. Speaks to a number of the team's players and staff members about their experiences. Notes that their 2011 record stands at 14-4 before playing in the Super 15 final against the Queensland Reds. Lists the distance travelled by the team, who did not play one game at their home ground during the 2011 season."

Author: "Williams, David"
Title: "Do you recognise this building? Clue : you are in Cashel Mall; Huge task ahead in central city; Tall buildings begin to disappear from city"
description: "Reports on the progress of the inner city demolition of earthquake-shattered buildings in central Christchurch. Lists the various buildings due for demolition."

Author: "Gamble, Warren"
Title: "Tale of two cities - the broken, and the shaken"
description: "Compares the effects of the earthquakes in the east of Christchurch, where there is major damage, and the west, where it is shaken but still functioning. Talks to a resident from Aranui and one from Bishopdale about the different levels of house and property damage they are experiencing."

Author: "McDonald, Liz"
Title: "Property players"
description: "Looks at how some property owners were dealt a better hand than others in terms of how the Christchurch earthquakes affected their properties. Describes some of the different outcomes people are faced with including the consequences of having or not having replacement insurance, having undamaged buildings available to tenants, and the suggestion of moving the central business district."

Author: "Hattaway, Peter"
Title: "Shaky finances"
description: "Gives a precis of recent NZ financial history, noting the collapse of many finance companies and the earthquakes in Christchurch. Looks at indications of debt in Christchuch becoming harder to collect, credit agencies taking a softer approach, and trends showing that credit card debt is becoming more of a burden for the middle class and that consumers are cutting back on it. Discusses the state of NZ finances and legal powers for debt collection"

Author: "Kitty, Robyn"
Title: "Building on water"
description: "Talks to landscape architect Di Lucas, about ROC (Renew Our City), and her firm notion of how post-earthquake Christchurch should be."

Author: "Madgin, Diana"
Title: "Violent blow to oasis of calm"
description: "Talks to Barry Gadsby, the owner of one of architect Peter Beaven's designed apartments in Cornwall St, St Albans, about his courtyard garden, a destination for hundreds of tourists over the years. Outlines the damage done to it by the Christchurch earthquakes."

Author: "Rae, Sally"
Title: "Young coffee devotee enjoys sweet success"
description: "Talks to the young bachelor of commerce student at Aoraki Polytechnic about her use of social networking, particularly Twitter, to establish the Italian-made Bezzera coffee machine brand in NZ. Mentions that she was living in Christchurch until the earthquakes, and provided eyewitness accounts for overseas news networks because of her social networking profile."

Author: "Haggart, Matthew"
Title: "Grappling with earthquake mayhem"
description: "Profiles the Dunedin-educated chairwoman of the NZ Historic Places Trust board. Talks to her about her education and career as a lawyer and judge. Describes the challenges facing the Trust in dealing with the effects of the Christchurch earthquakes on heritage buildings in the area, and comments on the need for more 'heritage artisans' to take charge of the architectural restoration of historic buildings. Cites other remarks she made to members of the University Club before the 13 Jun 2011 aftershocks in Christchurch."

Author: "Fisher, Amanda"
Title: "Hard lessons for shaky schools"
description: "Reveals that some 24 Wellington schools are potentially earthquake prone, listing the schools named by the City Council. Seeks comments from principals about the Council's findings. Discusses how the level of risk is assessed. Looks at the costs of strengthening the school buildings. Notes briefly the effects of pupil relocation resulting from the 22 Feb 2011 Christchurch earthquake."

Author: "Matthews, Philip"
Title: "Cover charge"
description: "Looks at pressures on the insurance industry of continuing earthquakes in the Christchurch area. Talks to Insurance Council chief executive Chris Ryan about the tensions between the reinsurers who insure the insurance companies and those involved in rebuilding the city. Describes the implications for commercial insurance in the future. Looks at legal issues arising around commercial leases and residential insurance."

Author: "Laugesen, Ruth"
Title: "Stress - cause, effect, and management"
description: "Speaks to local GPs in Christchurch about the increases in anxiety / stress related illnesses due to the earthquakes. Discusses research about how the immune system and nervous system can be affected by stress. Talks to professor Andrew Hill, head of Auckland's South Auckland Clinical School about his findings from a study about relaxation after surgery and its affect on recovery rates. Gives advice on beating stress."

Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"
Title: "Home truths"
description: "Looks at the effect of the recent Christchurch earthquakes on home insurance premiums and reinsurance. Supplies figures on the insurance cost of recent natural disasters. Looks at increases in contracting with international reinsurers and why some reinsurers are withdrawing from the market. Asks if NZ households may eventually be without comprehensive protection or be refused insurance on the basis of house inspections. Gives tips on what to look for when buying insurance and outlines the key issues arising from claims in Christchurch. Touches on how insurance company AMI has fared in the wake of the recent earthquakes."

Author: "Priest, Ceana"
Title: "February quake prompts move north"
description: "February quake prompts move north"

Author: "South, Gill"
Title: "Award winners have quake-city project"
description: "Award winners have quake-city project"

Title: "Your pass to the red zone"
description: "Presents an aerial view of the central business district (CBD) red zone of the earthquake damaged city. Includes some ground level images. Notes that the photographs were taken on 8 Jul 2011."

Author: "Anderson, Vicki"
Title: "Fracking : yes or no?"
description: "Reports that the controversial mining practice of fracking, which may trigger earthquakes and contaminate drinking water, could get the go-ahead in Canterbury. Speaks to Dr Paul White, senior groundwater scientist for GNS Science, Green Party environment spokesperson David Clendon, and West Coast-based geologist Dr Murry Cave, of Western Exploration, about the possible impact of the process on the region, and to L&M Energy managing director Kent Anson about the company's applications. Explains how fracking works. Briefly outlines some overseas fracking issues, including an Australian senate inquiry into its use in the coalmines of New South Wales and Queensland."

Author: "Haywood, David"
Title: "On your bike"
description: "Argues that the post-earthquake rebuilding period is the time to create a high-quality cycling infrastructure in Christchurch. Points to the successful Copenhagen method of encouraging people to commute by bicycle, which is usually known as 'Copenhagenisation'. Calculates how many litres of petrol would be saved in the city if people cycled at the same rate as those of Copenhagen. Considers the effects of cycling on public health. Touches on the results of an economic study in Portland, Oregon, after it underwent a Copenhagenisation in 2008. Looks at what needs to be done in the city to create a cycle network that appeals to commuters."

Author: "Wood, Alan"
Title: "Keeping calm and carrying on"
description: "Looks at the process of recovery from the Canterbury earthquakes for the region's manufacturing sector. Speaks to a number of local manufacturers and industry leaders, including John Walley, chief executive of the NZ Manufactures and Exporters Association, about some of the issues facing the sector, such as staff retention and the high value of the NZ dollar, and the rebuild process."

Author: "Killick, David,"
Title: "Grin and share it"
description: "Looks at examples of co-housing or common-ownership properties in Christchurch, Colorado and California. Describes the Clifton Hill development, the work of architect Roger Buck. Extols the benefits of shared facilities and communal resources. Suggests this type of housing may suit earthquake damaged Christchurch."

Author: "Killick, David,"
Title: "Grin and share it"
description: "Looks at examples of co-housing or common-ownership properties in Christchurch, Colorado and California. Describes the Clifton Hill development, the work of architect Roger Buck. Extols the benefits of shared facilities and communal resources. Suggests this type of housing may suit earthquake damaged Christchurch."

Author: "Matthews, Philip"
Title: "Quakes' many stories to go on the record"
description: "Reports on how the experience of the Christchurch earthquakes will become the most comprehensively studied and archived disaster in NZ's history. Speaks to National Library of NZ associate chief librarian Ronald Milne about how the library has been steadily working to amass an earthquake archive, which includes an oral history project, commissioned photographs, harvesting of earthquake-related websites, and earthquake-related ephemera. Backgrounds the launch of the Ministry of Culture and Heritage's new web project called 'Quake Stories'. Talks to Paul Millar, an associate professor in the College of Arts at Canterbury University, about the plans for the 'Ceismic consortium', which will see Canterbury build up a unique archive of quake experiences."

Author: "Smith, Charmian"
Title: "Concern for heritage inspires artist"
description: "Talks to the Wanganui-raised artist about 'Preoccupied', his survey exhibition of works from 1998, Monumental Gallery, Dunedin, until 4 Sep 2011. Informs that the exhibition (originally entitled 'Reverb') had been installed at the Centre of Contemporary Art (CoCA), Christchurch, but was disrupted by the 22 Feb 2011 earthquake. Discusses his involvement in saving heritage buildings and how he incorporates this interest into his paintings. Touches on the current situation for the arts communities in Christchurch after the earthquakes."

Author: "Matthews, Philip"
Title: "Archivists dig quake stories out of rubble"
description: "Reports on how the experience of the Christchurch earthquakes will become the most comprehensively studied and archived disaster in NZ's history. Speaks to National Library of NZ associate chief librarian Ronald Milne about how the library has been steadily working to amass an earthquake archive, which includes an oral history project, commissioned photographs, harvesting of earthquake-related websites, and earthquake-related ephemera. Backgrounds the launch of the Ministry of Culture and Heritage's new web project called 'Quake Stories'. Talks to Paul Millar, an associate professor in the College of Arts at Canterbury University, about the plans for the 'Ceismic consortium', which will see Canterbury build up a unique archive of quake experiences."

Author: "Dennis, Abby"
Author (detailed): "Abby Dennis, Meghan Scanlan and Greer Paterson"
Title: "It's simple to be safe on Facebook; No act of kindness to Earth is wasted; Christchurch quakes show technology's worth"
description: "Presents essays from three pupils at Roxburgh Area School on the topics of Facebook safety, environmental preservation and the value of technology."

Author: "Jillings, Kasia"
Title: "Quakes generate plans for off-grid homes"
description: "Quakes generate plans for off-grid homes"

Author: "Croot, James"
Title: "An instant time capsule"
description: "Talks to film makers Angus Benfield and Patrick Gillies about the comedy they made in Christchurch in 2009 that includes footage of city areas since destroyed by the earthquakes."

Author: "Fisher, David"
Title: "Reasons to hope"
description: "Reflects on the disasters that have hit the country in the last 12 months, including the Pike River Mine explosion, the Christchurch earthquake, and the Auckland tornado. Talks to West Coast Mayor Tony Kokshoorn, historian Professor Philippa Mein Smith from the University of Canterbury and Christchurch Mayor Bob Parker about the traumatic year."

Author: "Pepperell, Susan"
Title: "Hard times bring out our best side"
description: "Reports on how random acts of kindness can make the world a better place. Speaks to Megan Singleton who, along with three friends, started the annual Random Acts of Kindness (RAK) Day. Highlights some RAK events. Touches on some RAK after the 22 Feb Christchurch Earthquake."

Author: "Sachdeva, Sam"
Title: "Experts like what they see"
description: "Interviews two speakers at the International Speakers Series in Christchurch about their ideas for rebuilding the city after the earthquakes. Talks to Timaru born, London based architect Sam Martin about his concept of a park along the Avon River and his ideas for a central earthquake information centre. Talks to Victorian Bushfire Reconstruction and Recovery Authority  planner Kerry O'Neill about lessons learned in Victoria and her views on draft plans for Christchurch. Profiles briefly participants in the International Speakers Series being held at the University of Canterbury, 27-30 Aug."

Author: "Douglass, Malcolm"
Title: "The Draft Plan : five key matters"
description: "Presents opinion by the town planner on the post-earthquake Draft Plan document created by the Christchurch City Council. Sets out the five issues that the author considers need immediate resolution, focusing on council resources, public transportation, and development strategies. Provides a summary of the author's credentials."

Author: "Dekker, Diana"
Title: "Something to sing about"
description: "Throws the spotlight on myths about opera, noting the current health of the NBR New Zealand Opera. Previews the company's performance of 'Cavalleria Rusticana' and 'Pagliacci' at the St James Theatre, Wellington, 27 and 30 Aug, and 1 and 3 Sep. Discusses sponsorship, typical costs of production, surtitles, lean sopranos, ticket prices and audiences. Looks at the risks of staging lesser known operas, and the effect of low fees on NZ singers. Touches on the condition of Christchurch opera venues. Mentions the 6 Oct appearance of Placido Domingo at an earthquake recovery concert in Christchurch."

Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"
Title: "No more cheap home insurance"
description: "Looks at the effect of the recent Christchurch earthquakes on home insurance premiums and reinsurance. Supplies figures on the insurance cost of recent natural disasters. Looks at increases in contracting with international reinsurers and why some reinsurers are withdrawing from the market. Asks if NZ households may eventually be without comprehensive protection or be refused insurance on the basis of house inspections. Gives tips on what to look for when buying insurance and outlines the key issues arising from claims in Christchurch. Touches on how insurance company AMI has fared in the wake of the recent earthquakes."

Author: "MacFie, Rebecca"
Title: "Shocker; we were warned"
description: "Reviews Christchurch one year after its 4 Sep 2010 earthquake.  Relates the upheaval experienced by former Avonside resident and leader of citizens' group CanCern Leanne Curtis, whose house was in the red zone. Calculates the financial losses facing many red-zoned house owners.  Looks at how Kaiapoi couple Tetumu Rolleston and Luana Belworthy and their seven children have fared after their house was destroyed.  Describes the state of the building industry in Christchurch, noting the effects of delays in construction.  Points out the wary response of the insurance industry. Informs of a controversial geotechnical report published in 1991 and headed by now chief executive of Solid Energy Don Elder that warned of Christchurch's earthquake and liquefaction risks."

Title: "Something to sing about"

Author: "Dudding, Adam"
Title: "The year the earth shook"
description: "Talks to a number of scientists, including Dr Mark Quigley, senior lecturer in active tectonics and geomorphology at the University of Canterbury, about some of the lessons they have learned from the region's recent earthquakes and aftershocks."

Author: "Van Beynen, Martin"
Title: "City mourns loss of pioneer of quake protection technology : Robinson seismic founder"
description: "City mourns loss of pioneer of quake protection technology : Robinson seismic founder"

Author: "Carville, Olivia"
Title: "Death breaks family's heart; Widow finds comfort in daughter's act of bravery; Earthquake victim was a 'true romantic'"
description: "Death breaks family's heart; Widow finds comfort in daughter's act of bravery; Earthquake victim was a 'true romantic'"

Author: "Gilchrist, Shane"
Title: "Taking aim at the inane"
description: "Focuses on the NZ Skeptics. Speaks to NZ Skeptics media spokeswoman Vicki Hyde about the aims of the non-profit incorporated society, which she likens to a Consumer's Institute for the mind. Talks about the lack of science-based knowledge within the media. Touches on some of the poor or shoddy science the Skeptics have issues with. Mentions the society's 2011 'Bent Spoon Award' for journalistic gullibility, which was awarded to media outlets and personalities who took Ken Ring's earthquake prediction claims at face value. Notes that the NZ Skeptics 2011 annual conference is being held in Christchurch on 27-28 Aug."

Author: "Conway, Glenn"
Title: "Mayor an optimist in face of misfortune; One year on September 4, 2010"
description: "Interviews the Christchurch mayor one year after the Darfield earthquake. Talks about the effect on the mayoral election, and how he has fared politically, psychologically and personally."

Author: "Heather, Ben"
Title: "Shock to the system; extent of disaster never imagined"
description: "Explores criticism that the EQC was unprepared for the size of Christchurch earthquakes, for multiple earthquakes, and for the number of claims.  Talks to chief executive officer Ian Simpson about EQC's response to an external review (2008) that highlighted inadequacies.  Looks at the post-earthquake functions taken on by the Commission that are outside its mandate.  Asks if the EQC model is sound.  Briefly describes the function of the EQC. Shows statistics for claims and amounts paid for the 2010 and 2011 earthquakes."

Author: "Anderson, Vicki"
Title: "Reading signs before a quake"
description: "Talks to scientist Dr Neil Whitehead about his research into possible indicators of the 4 Sep 2010 Canterbury earthquake.  Notes that  the study of electronic precursors to earthquakes began in Japan after the 1995 Kobe earthquake. Discusses the detection of electromagnetic radiation signals in the ground, in water, in the sky, by animals, by humans, by electronic gadgetry, and in the form of earthquake lights. Mentions a successful earthquake prediction in Chian in 1975. Comments on the response from Cantabrians to his response for information."

Author: "Crean, Mike"
Title: "Scientist took the shakes out of the quakes"
description: "Scientist took the shakes out of the quakes"

Author: "De Lacy, Hugh"
Title: "Shell-shocked in the Shaky Isles"
description: "Observes the impact of the 2010 and 2011 Canterbury/Christchurch earthquakes on the insurance industry.  Talks to Insurance Council of New Zealand (ICNZ) chief executive Chris Ryan, Insurance Brokers Association (IBANZ) chief executive Gary Young, and AMI Insurance chief executive John Balmforth about the costs to insurers and reinsurers.  Highlights the current precarious state of AMI.  Speculates on how high insurance premiums will go up as a result."

Author: "Steeman, Marta"
Title: "Recovery stymied by insurance"
description: "Assesses the state of the Canterbury business community one year after the Darfield earthquake. Looks at the effect on CBD businesses of the 22 February 2011 earthquake. Provides some statistics on the state of various industries. Highlights the survival of Sydenham IT company Truescape, sheet metal fabrication shop Prometal, and residential building company Stonewood Homes."

Author: "Van Beynen, Martin"
Title: "'Fantastic' staff coped with chaos"
description: "Reports on the response and services provided by the Christchurch Hospital Emergency Department (ED) following earthquake in Christchurch. Points out six lessons learned, supplied by ED acting head Mike Ardagh."

Author: "Gorman, Paul,"
Title: "Savage shaking makes science sexy"
description: "Overviews coverage of the Canterbury earthquakes. Observes the public thirst for scientific knowledge sparked by the 4 September 2010 Darfield earthquake. Remarks on some of the egoic responses of scientists to suddenly being in the spotlight."

Author: "Matthews, Philip"
Title: "Beyond repair"
description: "Talks to Louise Deans about the destruction of the Homebush homestead in the Darfield earthquake. Recalls the events of the day, 4 September 2010. Reveals plans to build a new house close to the original site. Recalls Deans family history dating back to William Deans and John Deans taking up a lease in Canterbury in 1843, and the building of the homestead in 1851.  Documents damage to other buildings in Hororata - St John's church and the Hororata Hotel - and notes the creation of the Hororata Community Trust aimed at reviving the community."

Author: "Eleven, Beck"
Title: "Oh, how we've changed"
description: "Describes the social and cultural response of Canterbury to the 2010/2011 earthquakes that hit the region. Looks at changes in vocabulary ('munted'), dress and grooming codes, civic identity, house decoration, earthquake music and merchandise, and emergency preparations."

Author: "Shiels, Rosa"
Title: "Solid as a wooden rock"
description: "Highlights the research into earthquake resistant buildings by Structural Timber Innovation Company. Talks to Canterbury University engineer Dr Stefano Pampanin about the structure of the company's headquarters, a wooden building that withstood the 22 February 2011 earthquake. Notes his work with NZ born seismic designer Nigel Priestley, the use made of Greek temple structure, and the reason for focusing on using  wood. Mentions other buildings that use the company's earthquake-resistant technology."

Author: "Shiels, Rosa"
Title: "Solid as a wooden rock"

Title: "Scientist's quake bearings were 'NZ's greatest technological gift to the world'"
description: "Scientist's quake bearings were 'NZ's greatest technological gift to the world'"

Author: "Coldicutt, Ashleigh"
Title: "City accommodates quake-hit artists"
description: "City accommodates quake-hit artists"

Author: "Van Beynen, Martin"
Title: "Death in the classroom"
description: "Visits Toyama, Japan, to talk to students and staff of the Toyama College of Foreign Languages about their experience of the 22 Feb 2011 earthquake which destroyed Christchurch's  CTV building in which they were attending English classes at King's Education language school. Talks to College deputy director Kuniaki Kawahata about reconciling the death of his daughter Kyoko Kawahata in the earthquake. Speaks with four Japanese survivors of the quake and a NZer language teacher. Records the experience of the parents while in Christchurch to recover their children's bodies. Remarks on the resilience of the students who have resumed their studies in Japan. Relays the experience of NZ firefighter Paul Rodwell who rescued Japanese students from the CTV building."

Author: "Matthews, Philip"
Title: "Wellsprings of memory"
description: "Reports on 'The city as memory', and 'Imagined futures' panel discussions held in Christchurch under the auspices of the Scape public art biennial and Christchurch Arts Festival. Notes the poignancy of the discussion topics given the earthquake damage sustained on 22 Feb 2011. Summarises the views of the panellists art historian Jonathan Mane-Wheoki (on pre-earthquake Christchurch); landscape architect Di Lucas (on pre-human Canterbury); artist Anton Parsons, architect William Fulton (on the city's architectural influences); and Lyttelton sound artist and academic Bruce Russell (on social history and preserving ruins). Also presents the observations of landscape architect William Field (on public artworks created for Scape); Melbourne artist Ash Keating (on his installation Gardensity); Christchurch City Council urban design advisor Hugh Nicholson (on urban design); Auckland architectural critic and lecturer Bill McKay (about the pace of rebuilding); and Australian writer Simon Sellars (about urban renewal)."

Author: "Shiels, Rosa"
Title: "Staying put"
description: "Talks to immigrants who have settled in Christchurch about whether the recent earthquakes have shaken their resolve to stay in New Zealand. Talks to Britons Rachel Wiscombe and Joe Wiscombe; French brothers and chefs Frederic Berhault, Vincent Berhault and Benjamin Berhault; Americans Kris Woods and Jim Woods; Netherlander Anneke Vollebregt and Brazilian Mikael Ekman; and Britons Maria Romero and Nick Blackburn."

Author: "Croot, James"
Title: "City untouched in 'laying on of hands' tale"
description: "Reviews the film directed by Patrick Gillies and filmed in pre-earthquake Christchurch."

Author: "Van Beynen, Martin"
Title: "Lessons in grief; The 'worst day' for students' families"
description: "Visits Toyama, Japan, to talk to students and staff of the Toyama College of Foreign Languages about their experience of the 22 Feb 2011 earthquake which destroyed Christchurch's  CTV building in which they were attending English classes at King's Education language school. Talks to College deputy director Kuniaki Kawahata about reconciling the death of his daughter Kyoko Kawahata in the earthquake.
